reviewText: After seeing the Original release and then the Director Cut, I was a little disappointed.  The DC lacks the original voice-over by Ford that (imo) adds some sort of connection between the scenes.  The DC does have some extra footage that makes in worth viewing but not that much and the ending of the DC is different.  I believe that Blade Runner is still a great movie but I would have rather seen much more of the cut footage (like Decker visiting Holden in the hospital - a scene that is not in any released version) with the voice-over (narration by Ford).  Still it is worth watching and maybe adding to your collection.  END

I won't review or ramble on about the movies, it has been 35 years since the original Blade Runner, and most know what the movies are about.

I will comment, however, about the quality of the Blu Ray transfer of the movie - in Blu Ray, it is very clear and a nice upgrade from the DD - I was impressed by how crisp, clear the Blu Ray transfer was.  I viewed it on a 65" Panasonic VT60 Plasma, and it was very nice.  Not all Blu Ray transfers of older movies fare as well.  Note this movie was shot in 2:35:1, so the transfer didn't do anything about the "watch band" appearance on your 16x9 screen :-( but hey, that is a common thing.  I really like the 1:85:1 Anamorphic widescreen format for home movies but we can't have it all!

What is a bonus is that after almost 35 years, I STILL enjoy the movie.  And more importantly, so do my 18 year old boys - which says a lot about how well done this movie was - it is very entertaining.  I saw the original first movie in the theaters when it first came out, and I am still entertained from beginning to end.

So here we have a timeless movie which is still entertaining today, and one where the Blu Ray transfer allows you to watch it in crystal clear HD.  Awesome.

5 stars all the way!!!

This review is of the 4K version not the movie itself which is five stars. I thought the 4K disc wasn't any improvement over the blu ray disc. There were parts where I thought the 4K looked worse than the blu ray. Over processed. It seems like with such old source material there's only so much that can be done until the benefits max out. I'm watching this on a 4K television and 4K player and feel like if you have the blu ray there's no need to buy the 4K.

This movie is great for a 1980's-era film. The dolby Atmos audio and 4k are fantastic. However, the story is a bit slow, and both my wife and I had trouble staying awake through it.  Some of the writing was a bit cheesy, but very common for 80's films.  At first I wasn't sure if i really liked the film, and my wife actually wasn't willing to finish it.  However, after watching the new one, Blade Runner 2049 (which I give 5 stars), I have a much better appreciation for this film, because the second one (along with the handful of intermediate short films) really helped to complete the story.  Were it not for 2049, I would have given the original only 3 stars.  Please note that I'm not a big sci-fi junkie, and I think that it's the sci-fi junkies who overrate this movie, while the sci-fi averse actually underrate it.  It's good for what it is and what it was meant to be.

This movie really highlights the danger of falling in love with the photographic ambience of one's own set design. I'm watching this woman get charmingly gunned down by the hero in super-duper slow motion, and I'm thinking, why spend all this damn time on this? Yes, there are lots of pretty neon lights reflecting atmospherically and futuristically in all the glass here, but that's just not enough, Ridley; something needs to actually be happening here or it looks like you're just milking cool-looking photography and sets.

Other thoughts, in no particular order:

* There is some cruddy writing in this movie, but the Rutger Hauer dialogue in the climactic showdown appears to've been lifted directly from my six-year-old action figure battles. I felt like I was personally culpable for it.

* This music  oh my GOD, this MUSIC! I don't know where in blazes this music belongs, but it is not within a million miles of this movie. Like all the neon reflections and omnipresent smoke, it's atmospheric without having a purpose or philosophy behind it  not that I can detect.

* Same with all the Japanese blimp-advertisement-thingies. Is there an actual deep thematic statement Scott's making here, beyond the prediction that Japan would become more influential, or did he just think it'd look interesting to throw those in the mix?

* Wow, Harrison really just doesn't seem very interested in movies, does he?

* I'm not sure terminally ill escaped slaves work especially well as villains we want to see killed, and the romance is about as perfunctory as any I've seen.

* I liked the moment with the snake dealer in a fez. All one lengthy shot (you can see the camera reflected in the window, but who cares) and the dialogue is done like it's part of the background music. That's an inspired moment.

Don't get me wrong; I love cool, moodily lit sets way more than the next guy. But don't let them fool you into thinking there's more going on in a movie than there really is.

Finally, a "cut" of the movie (after so many disappointing ones over the years) that gets it (mostlly) right; one where the actual transfer is as good as the story.

The best thing about this film is the slow, sort of druggy pace and the cinematography. I love the feel of those darkly shot 80's films especially from 1980 to 84ish.
This film is what i call a brilliant failure in that it looks great but ends up being so commercial that any attempt to legitimize it on say a Solaris level goes right out the window within the first 10 minutes of the film.
I watch this film a lot along with other film that fall in to the brilliant failure category. Another example would be Dune. It is totally flawed but the scenes that are good are some of the best scenes ever.
I have to comment on the overratedness of this movie. I just saw a special edition of this that had a Tarkovskyesque horse on the from cover. This is laughable-again Blade Runner is not an art film but it want s to be.
What made the original Alien so good was Scotts use of silence and space and slow long takes. He brings some of that element into play here.

I finally got around to watching this movie. It's 2018, I didn't wait too long, eh? The setting is like Hong Kong in a never-ending monsoon, interspersed with futuristic decaying interiors. The huge cold inhuman Tyrell building and interior is just as dark, and is an inhuman contrast to the dirt and color of the very human alleys through which Harrison Ford tracks the replicants. The whole thing looks, sounds and feels dark, dirty and depressing.

So the Depression-era style hardboiled detective who drinks too much and falls in love with a beautiful but shady dame is put into the futuristic setting, but can't escape the cliches of the film noir old school detective story.

It is interesting to see how much the film "Fifth Element" draws from this film. I didn't know that before. Makes me appreciate "Fifth Element" more. It doesn't take itself so damned seriously.

Widely regarded as the most boring rom-com ever made, this movie bears up under the weight of passed time best when viewed through the beer goggles of nostalgia. Watch as Harrison Ford (played by renowned actor Harrison Ford of Star Trek fame) goes on the adventure of a lifetime in an alarmingly believable and increasingly prophetic vision of America circa 2019. Ford's journey takes him on a beautiful journey of self-discovery and critical examination of our notional concepts of humanity. It's snakes at every turn for our arch-browed, mumbling hero as Ford enchants and enslaves every robot he meets, whether they're on the big screen or in the audience.

I had remembered this film as a great hallmark of sci-fi when I was younger, and I was so looking forward to re-watching it. It was pretty late, so I'll admit that I was dozing off a little when my girlfriend paused the film and said,

"Hey...do you remember this movie featuring a rape scene? Are they really going through with this after she tried to escape his apartment, and he slams her against the window? I mean...she definitely tried to leave and is wincing right now."

I didn't remember this at all, but thinking back I knew that they did continue the scene. As it turns out, this film is another example where rape is normalized as acceptable behavior, even for the movie's hero / protagonist.

Despite the cool world-building, lighting, and camera work, I can no longer see this as a hallmark of sci-fi. It is an excuse for sexual violence against women. There are many other scenes where this behavior is prevalent, though arguably more subtle and easier to justify. I do not recommend that anyone watch this film.

I tried setting MNR up a notch but I think that made some of the higher motion scenes leave tracers- are either of these the fault of my blu-ray player or tv, or is this something common to blu rays (I probably haven't looked as intently at the image on the small number of other blu ray movies I've watched), or is this edition deficient?  Does the UHD Final Cut have these problems?

Okay, first things first.  Comparing this film to the future that so far has developed is absurd.  If people weren't so narrow minded in their appreciation of fiction, they could have set this movie in modern day NYC or Tokyo.  But people would be confused; "Robots don't have skin.  Does this take place in the future?"  Also, it gives the filmmakers an excuse to build exaggerated set designs and executing all kinds of visuals that otherwise would need to be "realistic" or be accompanied by a narrator to explain their presence.
With that aside,
The script and its corresponding visuals start out strong, and then, to my mind, gets bogged down in a siege of hardcore detective work.  I would assume in this instance that detective work does eventually lead somewhere, but I was a bit lost on what exactly he was looking for and how he came to the hypothesis that he was anywhere other than right where he started.  Also -- it's a second hand assumption that the detective work in this film is going to lead somewhere.  If one was not familiar with the concept of a story based movie, one would not have any reason to assume this.  Often, in reality, detective work, although a valuable thing, the fact is that detectives do not always find what they are looking for and the cases they are hired to solve often end up unfinished.  There is nothing happening during Indiana Jones/Han Solos' detective work except the introduction of characters who we learn nothing about and whose presence serves nobody except the screenwriter and the director.  The audience is expected to have such minimal expectations of a movie that they will have their jaw open in awe during all of this or insist on "seeing it through" until the end when they see how it all connects.  That's reality.  Thistles and thorns and a delicious meal afterward.  I'm not going to pay someone to deliver me a plate of uncooked fish.  I'll toil the land if i need to. This is a classic Sci-Fi film regarding the morality of humans making slave robots/androids. They are used for slaves, workers, warriors and lovers. The are outlawed because of a revolt on a distant planet and they are banned from coming to Earth for any reason. They are called replicants.

A Blade Runner is a professional assassin that is tasked with the job of terminating any replicant that returns to Earth for any reason. This is a look into the future of what Earth will look like in the future with overpopulation and fear of Artificial Intelligence creations. It is set in 2019 and it is funny to see what the director foresaw the year 2019 to be like. The original film was made in 1982.  I have watched it many times over the years.

Better it said, "The Final Gut." This butchered version of the great film removes much of the great writing that was in voice overs. They gave a critical dimension to the Deckerd character played by Harrison Ford. Worse still the final scene is cut from the film which gave in another, albeit romantic, but nonetheless more human ending. It has been suggested that Ridley Scott didn't want to use voiceovers as explanations when he first made the film, but was over ruled by studio execs. The execs were right. It made the film harken back to earlier film noirs, which the entire story of Blade Runner is a futuristic version of. The voice overs play a role like photographs in the film do, as representing an interior life, which the replicants aren't really supposed to have. In fact they're programmed to self-destruct in four years when they are likely to develop them. The character of Ray, played by Rutger Hauer, is the example. Specifically cites what he has seen and remembered and it it the reason he has ultimately developed an empathy that makes him save the life of Deckerd and hopefully pass on his experiences before his dying.

Review of an Amazon Video streaming of "Blade Runner: Final Cut" - Blade Runner: The Final Cut (I am incredibly annoyed that Amazon mixes reviews for the DVD, Blu-Ray, streaming, and other formats all under the same review headline!) In 1982 a friend and I decided to go see "Blade Runner" in the movie theater. Our other movie-loving friends had never heard of it and weren't willing to take the time to see it. I came out of that theater HOOKED! What an awesome movie! Fast-forward several years and I'm in college. At the video rental store I spy "Blade Runner: Director's Cut" on a shelf and convince my friends (many of whom were the ones who refused to see it the first time) to watch it with me that night. "What the heck?" Is all I had to say about halfway through. Suddenly the enjoyable movie had become some kind of art house project! They took away the narration of Harrison Ford, chopped and edited the flow of the movie into something less coherent, and generally left a very bad taste in the mouths of my friends who had never seen it before. It wasn't the movie it had been! Now fast forward thirty more years and I want my sons to share this movie with me. Unable to verify which streaming movie is the "original" I end up ordering "Blade Runner: The Final Cut." What a bunch of crap! Thanks to even more editing and remixing and cutting my sons will never have any appreciation for this movie whatsoever! I mean, its not like I expect them to always have clear storylines, as almost every single movie made today, but this "Final Cut" version is ten times WORSE than the "Director's Cut" was! BORING!

I bought this movie right before the sequel Blade Runner was released. One of my favorite movies based on one of my favorite books, "Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep" by Philip K. Dick.

This is one of the greatest works ever captured on film. This 1982 adaptation of Philip K. Dick's masterpiece "Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep" is deeply riveting and marvelously cinematically implemented manifesting in this sci-fi classic chase story placed in the backdrop of a dystopic 2019 LA with commensurate nuclear winter, the smell of Japanese noodle stands, and frozen synthetic eyeballs. Prepare to be fascinated on all sensory fronts--and realize that the world depicted in this film is unfolding now...By the way, the final soliloquy by R.Hauer is one of the best in movies, all time. Peace

An all-time Science Fiction classic, but not just of the genre, of the medium as a whole. Anyone who cares about either film or creative fiction should see this movie. A career highlight for everyone involved, and a creator of the cyberpunk aesthetic. Based on the excellent source material of Philip K. Dick, and with a very good sequel just out of theaters by the same screenwriter Hampton Fancher, and new director Denis Villeneuve.

I've enjoyed Blade Runner throughout the years. The aesthetic is phenomenal for the time it came out. I was fortunate to see a set piece at the Museum of the Moving Image (Tyrell Corp.) I give it four stars because it ushered in the way science fiction movies were made thereafter, but like the book, there's just something lacking. Still, worth watching.

I've been obsessed with Blade Runner forever and was gifted the 7 disc variations version in the "briefcase" released in 2007.

The ONLY one I recommend watching is the Director's Cut (1992).

The first movie has a hokey voice-over and tacked on happy ending. It's worth watching if you are a into costumes but that's about it.

The Director's Cut (1992) is the best because it doesn't have the voice-over or some of the weird, distracting things added in to the Final Cut version.

Most importantly, it didn't *change the language* in one of the best, most quotable scenes in the film, which I won't spoil here. I was SO upset that was changed in The Final Cut!!

Otherwise, the Final Cut (2007), does have the complete Unicorn Scene, but over all, the Final Cut is not worth watching at all unless you are a Blade Runner fanatic.
This movie is a classic, and this version, the original with Harrison Ford's voice over is the best.

In the second murder scene of a woman, her body is symbolically sexually desecrated. This is the most disgusting display of the, "fun" abuse of women. Then, and it shocks me Harrison Ford agreed to this, he traps a resistant woman and forces himself on her. Then asks if she loves him. Of course, after being forced, she is all over him! BOYCOTTING MOVIE #2

Simply declaring anything less than perfect is heresy, I know, but in truth this is a very, very flawed story that just happens to be gorgeously and very competently shot. It's a spectacle to behold, and the pacing is perfect - anyone who claims it's 'too slow' or thinks it 'drags on' has some issues with attention deficit (trust me, I know, I take pills for that!). The soundtrack is also fantastic, etc, etc - basically everything on a technical level is phenomenally well done That said, well...

The story is frankly very confused about what it wants to be (to be fair, even though it is VERY different from the source material, that's largely true of the book as well), the most interesting and compelling aspect of the entire thing largely happens in the background, with an ominous feel that condemns the existential questions it's supposed to be raising. Most even seem cool and meaningful on the surface, but after a moment of reflection you are left scratching your head as to why, for instance, a guy running through a crowded street waving a gun around and taking potshots at a woman doesn't even elicit a second glance let alone panic, why one replicant decides to spend her last few days performing stage shows with a snake instead of seeking the answers she came to Earth to find, or how a guy serving noodles that doesn't speak English is seconds later called over to translate, etc...

Maybe if the Replicants' story were the focus rather than Decker's, or if the writing didn't often contradict itself, or if the ham-fisted (and frankly rapey) romance wasn't shoved in where it honestly doesn't fit it, would have lived up to the hype.

It's still well worth a view, but for the love of Pete, lower your expectations if you want to enjoy it!

I actually believe I was speaking with someone at Apple support about their "personal assistant," and due to their recent IOS (multiple updates) that they are turning the iPhone into more of a social media device than anything else why can't they "upgrade" their "AI" rather than add 70 emogis. I mean, they more or less set the bar and yet other companies, like even Amazon, have surpassed what Apple's Siri character is capable of, and the support agent says to me "you mean like Blade Runner?" The two-disc set is the only way to go, and the 'final cut' is far better than the theatrical release. Like many people, I didn't much care for the film at first. However, I would watch anything Ridley Scott has directed, and the two recent Alien prequels are fine examples why. Moreover, look how he has progressed with the "artificial lifeforms" in those films.

In the end, Ridley Scott is simply a master of storytelling & visuals. And the final scene of the Final Cut, or at least the death of Rutger Hauer's character, says it all. The thought that this dystopian future takes place in 2019 will also give you something to wrap your head around.

To those that think this move is "slow and unappealing" I'd say watch it again. Philip K Dick was a very complex person. This story is ultimately about existentialism and the need to survive and that rooftop scene just brings it all together. I'll never forget this film. I'm glad I bought this and was able to share it with someone. The reality is, when you tackle these kinds of questions and put it in a screenplay, it's not about how fast the movie flows. It's the content and the concept. If you expected Mission Impossible 3 you'll be disappointed. This film is not about the action. It's a thinking man/woman's movie.

BR is of course a fantastic work of art. The final cut however is rendered too dark. So dark that previously visible fabric weaves from the directors cut are now just black. Compare the chapter where roy pops "time enough" and asks if Leon got his photos before heading over to chews eye shop. The directors cut has a ton of visible detail, but the final cut is over saturated with green resulting in lots of blacked out details. And lots of other scenes are just very green compared to the directors cut.

Also the additions, including a cgi background insert when the pigeon flies away, are not really needed, as are the deletions of the spinner wires.
One thing fun about blade runner the directors cut is watching it again for the many continuity gaffs, and misc body parts strewn around. Who's hand was that on Roys shoulder in the phone booth?  and why does he have the nail sticking out of the back of his hand in that same scene?? And who was that laying in the tub in the final where deckard and roy show some spirit??
Unfortunately the final cut has used some cgi to remove those little details and thus removed some of blade runners original mystique.

Classic, atmospheric, dark, futuristic noir of a retired blade runner (robot hunter/killer) forced to come back for one more job to terminate 4 off-world skin jobs who made it back to earth and are committed to killing their maker. Harrison Ford is great as a depressed, resentful retired detective, good at his job but tired of killing. Sean Young is the gorgeous, sexy secretary of the corporate executive who created the robot skin jobs that seduces Ford. This has all the elements of the old noir films and the best of the sci-fi ones with lots of philosophical musing of the infusion of souls by creators into creations a la Frankenstein.

One of them must be "Blade Runner in its many varied and excellent versions. This film is what sci-fi is all about. Instead of wasting time on gratuitous blood squirting, the story is much deeper with not only a message but a question.

"Early in the 21st century, the Tyrell Corporation advanced Robot evolution into the Nexus phase - a being virtually identical to human - Known as `Replicant.'"...Replicants were used Off-world as slave labor ...Replicants were declared illegal on earth ...Special police squads - Blade Runner Units - had orders to shoot to kill ..."

This was not called execution.
It was called retirement.

The film from beginning to end is treated with an overlay of original musing by the renowned Vangelis. In many films music can be a distraction or is needed to enforce spooky scenes. In this film the music is more of a co-character.

One image that staid with me is of Daryl Hannah with her fancy eye shadow.

It is now possible to see the many variations of this film based on the novel "Do Androids Dream of Electric Sleep" by Philip K. Dick.
Just about the only way left to get at the original and best release; the one with the narration. Adds so much atmosphere; still the only one worth watching!

Ridley Scott's science fiction opus gets the cut he deserved in what is effectively the Gone with the Wind of science fiction films. Yes, it's long, and yet so completely immersive you actually believe that this is a world that could exist. It's one of the things I love the most about watching Scott's films. I'm always complaining that many modern films trade in character development for action and CGI and that is not the case with Blade Runner. The attention to detail from a story perspective is brilliant, and whether it is a human or a replicant you want to know more about each and every person that crosses your path in the world that's been created here. Nothing is dismissed or used as a throw away. The performances are perfection and the line blurred between the humans and the replicants are chilling to watch as they interact with each other. I would say a film like this might not be geared towards a casual sci-fi watcher, but it is absolutely an important piece of cinema and totally worth watching.

Great movie

1. Stunning visual design, sets, f/x etc. First of its kind and really something to see (especially Joanna Cassidy)
2. Removes all of the themes of the book (e.g. what constitutes a living being?)
3. Rutger Hauer gives a hammy performance feels like he's in a different movie (except for "Tears in the Rain")
4. Story lacks suspense, no real conflict, Decker never really has much adversity he can't handle
5. Characters are very cold, it's appropriate for noir, but they are just not interesting or unique
6. Some supporting characters don't seem to serve much purpose (Gaff, Chew)
7. First 5 minutes and last two minutes are great, other than that, it's just borderline dull.

After DECADES of people telling me to watch this, I bought it and after watching it I just felt rather neutral toward it. While visually stunning, the editing was all over the place, the acting was rather inconsistent, and the story was not that cohesive. While I was able to follow the plot, and I didn't mind the dubbing of Ford's voice too much, the fact remains that no matter what cut of this I watch I've not found myself enjoying any of them that much more than the original cut.

And then there's the overly aggressive scene where Ford's character FORCES a partner to say what he wants her to hear in order to act like he was getting consent from her.

In all honesty, I can see why people feel strongly toward it if it's one of the first movies of this type you've ever seen, but I'd rather read the book than sit through it again.

I first saw Blade Runner in the theater back in 1982. The trenchcoat-wearing lawman hunting down the baddies thrilled me but nownowNow I realize I must have been in the grip of a fascist mentality.
 The reality is that Blade Runner is filled wall to wall with anti-heroes; Rachael being the exception.
 Watched the directors cut recently and was blessed in that I saw it a day after reading the New Republics review of Toni Morrisons important book The Origin of Others. For a demonstration of Morrisons thesis listen to the words of Captain Bryant in Blade Runner.
 Havent seen Blade Runner 2049 as of this writing so Im not sure how the story will be advanced.
 It would be amazing if the new film managed to pack in half of the warnings of the original. Ridley Scott saw pretty far using his 1980s binoculars  Environmental degradation (which helps transform the City of Lights  L.A.  into the City of Darkness), turning the justice system into a weapon for use by the invisible hand of monopolistic corporations, the questionable morality of genetic engineering, technology leading us back to the slave-owning mentality, anger at G-d/our maker, fake news (how accurate are the reports Deckard receives about the crimes of the replicants?), the opaqueness of peoples motivations (why did Deckard rejoin the Blade Runner force when he seemed to dislike killing? Why Gaffs in-action on Rachael?).
 Probably saddest of all is the only avenue of reestablishing trust in such a world is through willingness to do violence on behalf of each other.
 Maybe the new movie will take up Deckards possible replicant status and/or the fact that the entire Blade Runner corps may have been genetically engineered to kill the other (heres Morrisons others idea again) replicants to whitewash the failings of Tyrrell Corp. Maybe Rachael really is Tyrrells niece. Gaffs name is pregnant with possibilities. Is he someones mistake and, if so, whose?
 Ill admit to liking Deckards narration which is omitted from the directors cut. The uplifting ending is also not in the directors cut. Scott likely wanted to convey that most people don't go that route yet sit and make do. Its probably this same mentality that causes people to not walk out on violent past-times like football and hockey even when the injuries are severe and violence reaches a fever pitch.
 Yes, were all sinners. Maybe the replicants are sinners, too, although another question might be Do they have free will and, if so, how did they come by it?
 Sports are past times and as the cover of Wendell Berrys Home Economics says To live is not to pass time but to spend time. Blade Runner is a worthwhile investment of time because its important to realize where we are and why we still have much to lose.
Great sci-fi noir film with Ford before he became super famous. Avoid the director cut and the sequel, they blow big time. This one is the real deal.

Perhaps among the best all time films ever made, (that will eventually creep up on everyone like Casablanca).  It has depth, though dark and dreary -- (and one does wonder why Sean Young would wear a chinchilla-like coat in the pouring rain) -- but ever intriguing and interesting, and not blasted through with unnecessary sex and nudity.  This particular version was by the studio in the early 90's, sans the theatrical original's voiceover; Ridley's personal "Final" cut was not out until 2007.  Truly doesn't make much difference which one you get.  Yes, the later blu-ray's are sharp and clear, indeed.  But the blurry print of this one can't be help, and still lends to it's overall mystique.  The music track is also that perfect blending of sound and atmosphere and ambiance, forever superb.  A story well told, touching, and sticks with you long after.  Its truths, plainly eternal.
(And the issue of Deckard: a replicant or not?  An airy question, never solved.  The ambiguity is part of the magic.)  Enjoy.

Unfortunately, I sadly have to say, the sequel, 2049, was so convoluted I didn't have a clue what was going on from after the first kill.  Nothing after that made two drops of sense, much less "one."  Very, very, very disappointing.

EDITED: So apparently a bunch of people found the above review "unhelpful", so I'm adding this to clarify and add specifics. I never watched this when it was all the rage, I checked it out specifically because the 2049 one is in theaters and I wanted the backstory. Basically, I cannot conceive why there was such a fuss about this when it first came out...was it just that people's minds were boggled about robots that were rebellious or self aware??? was this like a version of dystopia that seemed cool and edgy at the time?...and I am now reconsidering seeing the new one because this was THAT BAD.

The plot was nonsensical and painful to follow. The dialogue was confusing, and the sound editing was significantly to blame. Harrison Ford did a really bad job of getting me to give a flying frack about him as a person, but then again I didn't really care about the other characters either. The startling random bits of casual racism and sexism and unexplained nudity and weirdness were jarring but not unexpected for the time frame of the film's production, but there was nothing redeeming that made me want to overlook those aspects either.

That's not to even get into the fact that the futuristic vision of technology that was presented here requires us as audience members to suspend a LOT of what we know about how technology actually works to buy into the basic premise. Basically, having a cop whose entire job it is to hunt down evil murdering robots (who are evil and murdering because they are self aware and consider themselves slaves) in the year 2019, one whose main method of discovering if they are robots is a freaking QUESTIONNAIRE AND EYE TRACKER, when our current 2017 technology would present several easy solutions to this problem -- tag all robots with Bluetooth or wifi trackers so you don't lose the murdering ones? x-ray the robots or have them go through scanners so we can detect their robotitude? make software that prevents them from knowing that they are slaves, or makes them enjoy it or be numb to it, or shuts their functioning down when they try to get all murder-y? -- is a bit too much.

Wow, I feel bad dissing a classic like this but I just spent the last 2 hours bored out of my mind.  I understand that this might have been ground breaking work in its time but I also remember skipping it 'back then.'  It looked dark and depressing when it came out and it was dark and depressing now.  There was almost no dialog.  The premise is also a bit weak because it doesn't properly explain why this blade runner, who had quit the agency, was somehow compelled to come back to kill the 4 rogue replicants.  His chief just says he has 'no choice' and the blade runner accepts that as fact.  The relationship between the blade runner and the female replicant is blase and unbelievable.  There is zero chemistry and no love.  It is past believing when he asks her if she loves him and she says she does.  There is simply nothing to feel in this movie.  It rains a lot.  The sky is polluted.  The buildings are ugly.  Cars fly even though there doesn't appear to be any regulations, signs or systems in place to keep them from hitting each other.  Basically, I feel like I wasted 2 hours.  And I LOVE science fiction.  If I didn't have such respect for Ridley Scott and the place this movie plays in history, I would have given it two stars.  Maybe even one.  I suppose that's just what happens to old movies after we've learned from them and moved on.  They don't entertain like they used to.  Those who loved it in the past might still love it.  Those who have never seen it will probably feel as I do.  Sorry, fans!

Blade Runner has always been one of my favorite movies, so it was a no brainer for me for purchase the 4k version. I had watched the theatrical, the European version, the director's cut (from 1992), but had never watched the Final Cut. By the time the final cut had come out, I felt enough was enough. It felt too "Lucas-y" to me. My initial thought when I discovered the Final Cut was the only print in 4k in this set was disappointment. That is until I hit play on the player. The Final Cut is absolutely gorgeous in 4k. If you like Blade Runner in any of its former editions, this one trumps them all. The audio is exquisite as well. IMHO this is the best iteration of a 4k print to date. If you're on the fence about getting yet another edition of this movie, GET IT! You won't be sorry you did.

Los Angeles, 2019. The Earth is grimy and grim, covered with vast cities of towering skyscrapers. Most animal life has been wiped out, replaced by expensive synthetic counterfeits. Counterfeit humans - replicants - also exist, carrying out dangerous, dirty work in the offworld colonies. For security their lifespans are limited to just four years. Four replicants have come back home, seeking to extend their lives. A replicant-hunter, a blade runner, is sent to stop them.

Blade Runner was released in 1982, a movie by Ridley Scott based (loosely) on Philip K. Dick's short novel Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep? The film had an initially mixed critical reception, but this improved with the release of the 1991 Director's Cut, which restored a subplot raising the question of if the central character of Rick Deckard (Harrison Ford) is himself a replicant. This cut also removed a series of unnecessary voiceovers and a studio-mandated "happy ending" that Scott had hated. In 2007 this version was superseded by the Final Cut edition, which restores some more scenes and tweaks others whilst completely digitally remastering the film in proper high definition (with eye-popping results).

The power of Blade Runner does not lie in its story - which is slight - but in its visuals, atmosphere and in its thematic exploration of the nature of what it is to be human. The replicants appear to be intelligent, sentient and capable of emotion, so the decision to use them as slaves is morally dubious; on the other hand they are also capricious, child-like and do not have an innate value for human life, killing those who oppose them with ease and ruthlessness. Deckard starts the film as a man of apparent moral certainty, willing to execute replicants. His meeting and association with Rachael, a cutting-edge replicant with much more human characteristics, raises doubts in him about his certainty that the replicants are soulless machines that need to be put down.

This is mirrored in the story of Sebastian (William Sanderson), who has a terminal disease and is spending his dying days creating new replicant technology for the Tyrell Corporation. This gives him tremendous empathy with the replicants, who are likewise doomed to die far before their time, and explains why he wants to help them (a decision he later comes to regret). This storyline is not as explored in as much depth in the novel - where a character named Isidore plays the same function and has a bigger role - but it does give some humanity to the replicants.

These themes of using artificial life to question what it means to be human would be revisited just a few years later in the character of Data in Star Trek: The Next Generation, but much more powerfully in the 2003 reboot of Battlestar Galactica (which also inherits Edward James Olmos as an actor and the term "skinjobs" for its replicant-like artificial lifeforms).

The movie's most enduring quality is its startling visuals: the vast, towering blocks of Los Angeles, the flames roaring into the sky from towers, police cars flying in front of colossal advertising hoardings. Disregarding realism (even in 1982, the idea of earthquake-prone Los Angeles looking like this just thirty-seven years later was a stretch), these visuals have lost none of their power and have even gained new power through their high definition remastering. Backed by Vangelis' haunting score, the sweeping effects shots of the city remain powerful and arresting in a way that the disposable CG cityscapes of modern SF movies cannot match. But beyond the effects footage is the minimalist way Scott shoots his futuristic, dystopian city, with dusty offices, bustling street markets and sparse apartments all looking amazing.

Performances are stripped-back, honest and raw: Harrison Ford, Sean Young, Daryl Hannah and Rutger Hauer all give career-best performances, whilst Edward James Olmos does a huge amount with a small amount of screen time. The film is sparsely-written, sparing with dialogue but making sure almost every conversation is important and memorable. This culminates in the movie's ambiguous and much-debated final confrontation between Deckard and Batty (Rutger Hauer), and Batty's soliloquy on his impending death and the loss of his memories, although he tries to impart some of these to Deckard through his "tears in the rain" speech.

For those who like their movies to be clear and unambiguous, Blade Runner will likely frustrate. This is a film designed to raise questions, engage in philosophical debates and have viewers revel in its slow-burn atmosphere and visuals. There are action sequences, but they are awkward, ugly and brutal rather than visceral and exciting. The so-called love story element is strange and questionable. The ending is ambiguous and, for some viewers, abrupt. But it's also a supremely assured film that is confident in its own ambition and executes it perfectly.

Blade Runner (*****) is strange, haunting and utterly compelling. There are numerous versions available, but arguably the Final Cut is the strongest, representing the director's clearest vision of the story.

A sequel, Blade Runner 2049, will be released on 5 October 2017 in the UK and a day later in the US. There are also three sequels in book form, written by K.W. Jeter, but these have been superseded by the new film.

I was blessed to be born in an era where I could go see Blade Runner, the Theatrical Cut, in the movies.  I wasn't old enough for "R" rated movies, but back then, that wasn't really a big deal.  You just asked a guy in his twenties in line to buy the tickets for you, then went in while a kid from school was taking tickets.  Easy Peasy.  After seeing Runner 4 times while in the theatre, working extra baby-sitting jobs and selling donuts at the local shop every Sunday, I was a 'nerd girl' though back then that wasn't even a term.
Now, fast-forward some years, the "Director's Cut" came out.  Personally it was 'ok'.  Took a bit to get used to Deckard's voice being gone, but this cut was good, extra stuff, etc...
Now!! I'm sitting with my 17-yr old son in a movie theatre when a trailer starts and within the first 3 seconds of just a visual and a couple notes of music, I KNEW.... I KNEW!!! OMG!!! I actually said that out loud in the theatre... OMG! Blade Runner!!! My son looked at me, cringed a bit, wished he had a different mother for that brief few seconds, but after watching a trailer, he was HOOKED!! On the way home from the movies we didn't even discuss what we watched, and honestly I can't remember, we only discussed Blade Runner, the story, the book, the movies, dystopian films, for a couple hours my teenage son suddenly saw his stay-at-home, Betty Crocker mom as 'somewhat' cool. LOL!
This weekend I purchased "Blade Runner: The Final Cut".... OMG!!! Talk about blown away!  I felt like a Blade Runner virgin all over again!  Ridley Scott finally got hold of everything he wanted to make HIS cut. And he made it beautifully!!!
(Note: the Director's Cut is NOT endorsed by Ridley Scott. He had nothing to do with it, has stated that on his Blog several times. While he doesn't dismiss the work, he does not endorse it)
The music, the added scenes, the lengthened unicorn sequence, and there are some twists that might surprise many of you that have only seen the Theatrical Cut.  PLUS, I sat with my son during this viewing.  He experienced something everyone, in my opinion, should experience once in their lifetime. The movie that started it all in the dystopian universe of gaming, movies, books (post Philip Dick), even the Steam Punk revolution.  My son, all 6 ft and 17-yrs old, got it!  He himself said, this explains so much in so many things I've read, games I've played, movies I've seen. A profound statement he made was "It's like this is the Rosetta Stone of science fiction today!!!"
IF you want to see the movie before you go to "Blade Runner 2019" in October, THIS is the version to see or the Theatrical Cut.

I rented the movie streaming twice, then decided to buy it because I knew I'd want to watch it again and again. This film has influenced so many other movies (not to mention video games and books) and is so packed with iconic film noir gems (not to mention comic book facial expressions and marvelously dark, corny lines), I find I glean something new from it with every viewing. The music was also clearly ahead of it's time, with the deliberate blending of acoustic and synth instruments mirroring the film's theme of organic v. artificial human presentation, worth and validity, though I have to chuckle at the use of saxophone in the "romantic scenes." While on the subject, I feel pretty skeptical about the authenticity of a "romance" between an assassin and his doomed target... but I digress. Uncomfortable kissing scenes aside, this movie is awesome.

4K UHD REVIEW: Do not hesitate. Buy this now! You won't regret it. If you are like me and have been frustrated by the lack of good quality 4K UHD movies, this is a must own! First off, most of the 4K UHD library to date is how shall I say... pretty horrible. I have purchased most of them after buying a top of the line 4K UHD TV, a top of the line 4K UHD player, and an Dolby Atmos Surround System. Unfortunatly, I was also a heavy investor in HD-DVD, which I now see 4K UHD having basically the same fate. For starters, by the time people finally get around to understanding 4K UHD, we will already have 8K TV's, so I don't see it lasting, especially with the fact that the movies that are being chosen are so bad, with the exception of a handful. The Blade Runner 4K UHD on the other hand, is not only an amazing and timeless classic, but it also is SPECTACULAR in 4K. If you have seen this movie various times like myself, you will instantly be able to tell that this 4K transfer is legit. So, in closing, at the moment, this is really the only REALLY GOOD movie and REALLY GOOD 4K movie I can recommend owning. Get it before it is gone, cause trust me, 4K UHD will not last. It's the HD-DVD of my generation, and the Laser Disc of the generation before me.

I know it's a cliche to say this, but I'm not sure this movie will ever look better than this 4K version. I've owned SO many copies of this movie. The old letterboxed VHS Director's Cut, the Theatrical Cut on DVD, the Director's Cut on DVD, the Final Cut on Blu-Ray, and all the versions that came with the Collector's Edition Blu-Ray version. I'm a BIG fan of this movie and have all the lines memorized.

But to my mind, there's no topping this as far as quality of image goes. The exterior shots of the Tyrell Corp. especially are as sharp as they've ever been - in part because they aren't obscured by Scott's directorial obsession with smoke. The street views come to life in a way I've never seen before, and because the image is so clear and sharp there's so much more detail to be seen.

The one strange issue I had was in the opening sequence, my TV had some dark black spots along the bottom of the screen when the fires flared during the overhead shot of Los Angeles, November 2019. I haven't seen any other reviews that mention this bizarre image problem, and I strongly suspect it may be a symptom of my cheap 4K TV's incompatibility with HDR.

The most important thing though is that this is faithful to the film. It looks like it was shot on film, and it doesn't look glossy and digitized. The whole point of 4K is to get a natural appearance that's as close to the film print as possible. I have a 4K TV that doesn't have HDR, so I can't speak to the HDR elements yet, unfortunately. However, from other reviews I've seen online, the HDR combined with the 4K elements means that this movie will probably never look superior to this version. Assuming the 4K Blu-Ray format never dies, this may be the last version of the movie I may ever buy again.

The only thing missing is extras. There are extras that were included on the 30th anniversary edition (assembled in 2007) that aren't on this one, and that means that there will probably be an "Ultimate 4K Edition" down the road that not only includes the gorgeous 4K version, but all the extras that will truly put the complete Blade Runner experience in one package. Until then, my advice is to hold onto your Blu-Ray version of the 30th Anniversary Collector's Edition.

Blade Runner finally comes to 4K! But it's not without some issues.

Right off the bat, the movie looks fantastic in 4K. You will need a 4K TV and 4K UHD Blu-Ray player to play this disc. I'm reviewing this on the OPPO UDP-203 player and LG OLED 65" c6p model.

The set includes a slipcover, 4 discs and a digital copy code. HDR is HDR10 (not dolbyvision, from what I can tell) and audio is in Dolby Atmos (I don't have atmos, so it comes across in TrueHD).

The discs are where it becomes a mess.
Disc 1 = The Final Cut 4K UHD Blu-Ray
Disc 2 = The Final Cut Blu-Ray (this is the same exact disc from the 2007 Blu-Ray release)
Disc 3 = Dangerous Days (documentary) DVD (that's not a typo.. this is a DVD disc inside of a 4K release) from the 2007 Blu-Ray
Disc 4 = Some people get a special features disc w/ the Workprint edit.. some people get 3 cuts of the movie (US Theatrical, International theatrical, Directors cut) on Blu-Ray, also from the 2007 Blu-Ray release.

There seems to be some confusion here. I don't know why Warner is including the 2nd, 3rd and 4th discs from the 2007 release (but leaving out 2 of the other discs from that set) and not including the discs from the 2012 release (or re-doin'g them for the 2017 release).

The 2007 releases already had issues (such as compression to match the HDDVD releases) so the quality of these discs 2, 3 and 4 do show their age.

The 4K UHD disc (why you're buying this!) does shine though. The film is very grainy (a tight grain, similar to TV static) but there is a noticeable amount of sharpness, clarity, better colors and HDR used throughout. Compared to the Blu-Ray, this is one definitely worth upgrading. If you don't like grain though, this may be one to pass on. If you've seen the Fifth Element 4K release, this is similar.

Unfortunately, the extra features (many of which are presented in 480p/DVD quality) are a very big disappointment. The 4K disc only includes a commentary, intro and trailer. The 7+ hours of features are across the other discs.

The movie itself is only presented in 4K as the "Final Cut" (not the original theatrical or directors cuts). The Workprint cut (which many do enjoy!) seems to only be included with some sets, while others (like me) received the disc with the theatrical and directors cut blu-ray's instead.

Audio is very good. I don't have atmos, but even on a 7.1 setup it sounds great. Also included is a digital copy that redeems in 4K.

Overall, nice upgrade if you own the previous sets.. If not, this is the one to get.

The first 40 minutes or so are pretty good ... you've got the problem of trying to determine who is human and who is a nasty android. All right - I'm ready for some mind games! And the production values are really good ... a futuristic world that looks cool and believable but also is kind of depressing at the same time.

But from there on out the story is just ... well, it's dumb, really. Just a bunch of stupid fight scenes. And when I say "stupid" fight scenes, I mean it. Especially the one where the girl is trying to kill him by practicing crazy acrobatics and he just takes out his gun and shoots her. That exact same thing was done in "Raiders of the Lost Ark" for laughs, but here we're supposed to take it seriously.

Sorry ... just because it looks cool doesn't make it a good movie.

The subject is neonoir cinema. The film screened are ROMEO IS BLEEDING (1993)  and BLADE RUNNER (1983). The discussion arises as to what the "true" version of the film is, or of any film, when there is a discrepancy between the theatrical cut and the director's cut. Ultimately, to the surprise of many of us, the theatrical cut wins the discussion. That was probably the last time that the debate ever ended in that outcome.

In the endless myriad versions of BLADE RUNNER that exist I humbly suggest that this, the Director's Cut, is the version a neophyte should turn to as a beginning. Personally I deny knowledge of any and all of the other versions on the market and the ridiculous extravagance afforded to this somewhat overly worshipped film. So get the cheapest version that is available. If that version does not satisfy or leave your curiosity piqued all of the added footage in the world is not going to make much difference. (Three and a half plus stars out of five)

BLADE RUNNER, 1982. Director Ridley Scott went back into post production to create this long-awaited definitive new version, Blade Runner: The Final Cut to celebrate the 25th anniversary of this iconic sci-fi masterpiece. It is spectacularly restored, remastered from original elements. Contains never-before-seen added/extended scenes; added lines; new/improved special effectsalthough, still, no computer generated effects; director/filmmaker commentary, an all-new digital audio track and more. And even some welcome cuts. So calling this treatment of Blade Runner long awaited is actually a resounding understatement.

Its been well worth the wait. Director Ridley Scott has now created the definitive version of an iconic, visually stunning, highly intelligent film. By far its best version. Even backed  with a staggering extra features package that varies depending on for whatever version of the release you opt). But the highlight nonetheless remains the stunning film itself, which remains a testament to creative people whose thinking was well in advance of  their contemporaries.

The core of Blade Runner, of course, remains the same. It opens in the then futuristic year of 2019, Los Angeles, California. Which has become a dark depressing metropolis, filled with urban decay, greatly Asianized, where, despite its being by geology a desert city, it seemingly always rains.  The film presents an amazing cityscape proven to be well ahead of its time, with resounding visuals that defied 1982s supposed limited special effects.

The handsome young Harrison Ford stars as Rick Deckard, ex-cop, "Blade  Runner,"  one of the persons assigned to assassinate "replicants. Androids that look like real human beings, have been given great artificial intelligence, greatly resemble their human models, but have been created with life spans limited to four years. Four replicants, anxious to have their life spans extended, stage a bloody mutiny on an Off World colony, steal a spaceship,  return to Earth to find their creators, call them to rights. Deckard is called out of retirement to track them down. As he does, eliminating them one by one, he comes across another replicant, Rachel, who evokes in him human emotion, despite her replicanthood. As Deckard closes in on the leader of the replicant group, he begins to question his own identity in this future world, wonders what's human and what's not.

The picture was based upon a story by Philip Dick, written by Hampton Fancher and David Webb Peoples, directed, of course, by the great Ridley Scott. It boasts a beautiful, emotionally evocative score by Vangelis. Leading actor Ford, then at the beginning of his long, still-prospering career, so young he sometimes doesnt look like the actor we know, carries the picture manfully. He is backed by an all-star cast, including Rutger Hauer as Roy Batty, leader of the insurrection; Edward James Olmos as Gaff, Deckards odd-ball coworker; M. Emmet Walsh as their boss Bryant; Darryl Hannah as Pris, replicant built to please; Joanna Cassidy as Zhora. replicant built to fight. William Sanderson as JF Sebastian, one of the replicants designers; James Hong as Hannibal Chew, another unfortunate replicant designer.  Each actor plays his/her part with an intensity rarely seen on screen; Hauer makes his great deathbed speech truly memorable.

Heres the time for me to mention an inconvenient truth: I loved this film back in 1982, love it still, and bought this DVD to replace a VHS tape I finally had to give away.  Like the improvements, but loved the original even so. And I am well aware that those Hollywood idiots, not content with greatness, are currently remaking the film in Prague.  Now Prague is a great, beautiful historic city, Ive been there and I know, but it aint LA. LA serves as another character in the movie. It is irreplaceable, its history such as it is, its historic buildings, such as the Bradbury Building, which is heavily used in the film. And I know that compared to Pragues buildings, the Bradbury is a baby.  But thats not the point. And how can you replace young Harrison Ford  surely not with the still scantily bearded Ryan Gosling.  Nor can you replace the remarkable Dutch actor  Rutger Hauer. Or Edward James Olmos, Emmet Walsh, James Hong, William Sanderson,  Joanna Cassidy, Darryl Hannah. Sorry, I may yet be forced to eat my words, but I don't know why Hollywood insists on trying to remake films successful, at least in part, for outstanding performances.  We shall see.  Meanwhile, I have loved this film since 1982.

There's a certain amount of patience that you have to have watching it though because unlike today's movies, the noir style feeling of this movie can seem like something of a drawn out torture (cue synth music that was popular in the late 80s, early 90s).

Over all, I'd say it's something that ever sci-fi fan should see at least once.

Do Androids Dream Of Electric Sheep? (1968) ...is a cultish favorite Philip K. Dick novel which young Sci-Fi aficionado's such as I went scrambling to unearth after we were mesmerized by his classic masterpiece The Man In The High Castle, the novel which brought him legions of fans.  Philip was an unusual writer with an ability to write both in a very literary style and yet come across in a very contemporary ease.  He was also a unique thinker in science fiction stories, being able to plow new troughs instead of retreading old worn out paths like most pulp novelists of the time were doing.  This is still a fact today and yet amazingly enough, new readers of Dick's stories will find fresh ideas that were written in the 60's.  The movie The Adjustment Bureau is a fine example of an old science fiction tale (The Adjustment Team) by Dick which is novel and intriguing in the 21st Century.  This is probably a main reason his works are now coming to film and TV in abundance (Next, Total Recall, Minority Report, A Scanner Darkly, Screamers, The Adjustment Bureau, and now on Amazon TV, The Man In The High Castle).  In 1981, Ridley Scott was making a new epic based on a relatively unknown (by public standards in 1981) sci-fi authors story!

So BLADE RUNNER had audience appeal as a spectacle film to the some audience theater goers, but to geeky Sci-Fi fans and not-so-geeky movie fans in general, it developed a near cult status over a period of just a decade following its theatrical release. It was not that successful on initial release because Indiana Jones now looked like a depressed Philip Marlowe and the Film Noir narration was seriously lacking even though the dystopian color affected a Film Noir feeling.  The cinematic style was a huge leap far and above the actual plot and script, so you had a gorgeous film with rather weak main character delivery.  If you are new to Blade Runner you may want to skip the Theatrical Version of the movie right away and save it for later viewing.  The film went through several incarnations thanks to some interesting theaters that began showing "Road Show" prints of the film a decade after its initial run, these somewhat rare vault copies energized new interest in the film and what we got resulted in a 1992 "Directors Cut" without the tough guy voice over and without the "happy ending" (it in fact more closely resembles the original Dick story).  Also included in this set is a 1982 "International" version which played mainly in Europe and had extended scenes to the Theatrical version.

The main draw here is 25th Anniversary "Final Cut" assembled by Ridley Scott and which is so superior in so many ways to any other version that it makes Blade Runner into a wholly new and absolutely perfect film.  Now Harrison Ford seems to fit better and more interesting than before (or maybe it just is a matter of age and the era in which we live, post-911).

There are featurettes in abundance on the 4th disc (The Enhancement Archive), if you are a Sci-Fi geek somewhere on a par with Sheldon Cooper, this will be your pee-in-your-pants bonus disc, but even if you are not, Dek-A-Rep and the two about the novel and the author are very interesting to watch and highly recommended.

The Final Cut took over 10 years to complete by Ridley Scott and one can see how painstakingly meticulous he paid attention to detail, especially if you have the gumption to watch it back to back against the Theatrical version.

Without spoilers, when watching this film, you will find subtly a treatise on what it means to be human and what it means to have a personal identity, in a rough way it ponders (not nearly as well as) the same questions brought up in Steven Spielberg/Stanley Kubrick's classic AI, Artificial Intelligence.

Blade Runner had to work really hard to become a "classic", but when one considers the director and his many masterpieces delivered over the years (still going strong by finishing up the Alien series with finality and about to embark on making Justin Cronin's PASSAGE trilogy into three films), one has to give a big nod to this as a real work of cinematic art and Ridley Scott is truly one of the best directors of modern times.

I purchased this over 7 years ago and have managed to watch everything on the four discs at least once, and the Final Cut about once a year, the other versions at least twice each in that time, so entertainment value versus price is premium!

Blade Runner: The Four-Disc Collector's DVD Edition vs. the Five-Disc Ultimate Edition are the same EXCEPT for the Five-Disc has the film known as the "Work Print" and the excellent documentary "All Our Variant Futures". I love the Four-Disc set and give it 4 stars, would have given it 5 stars if it also had the work print. My recommendation is if you can buy any Five-Disc set (also available on BLU-RAY) for about the same price as the Four-Disc, you should get that instead.

Below is the order I recommend watching all the versions of the film along with the other features in the set. If you only want to watch one version, it's a toss up between the International Theatrical Cut and Final Cut. I recommend watching at least the International Cut and Final Cut along with Dangerous Days.

Disc 3: US Theatrical Cut (1982)

Disc 3: Director's Cut (1992) This version is without the happy ending or narration over the film

Disc 2: Dangerous Days: a 210 minute documentary on the complete making of Blade Runner (and every minute is worth watching)

Disc 5: The Work Print and the Featurette "All Our Variant Futures" (Nether included in the Four-Disc set)

Disc 4: Enhancement Archive: Has many features including nearly an hour of deleted scenes

Disc 3: International Theatrical Cut (1982) Basically the US version with some added violence (My favorite of all versions)

Disc 1: The Final Cut (2007) Almost the same as the Director's Cut but has some great tweaks and is a very clean film

I am a bit of a fan of noir-styled films of gritty detective thrillers and/or whodunit films. Needless to say, one of my favorite aspects of the theatrical/original version of "Blade Runner" was the narration voice-over by Ford throughout the film. The film was (at the time) 40 years into the future and despite this "distance," that narration gave it a very personal feel. You as the viewer were far more able to relate to Ford's character Deckard's cynicism and general loner personality. It also lent a vintage feel to a futuristic film. The detective's narration in a gritty crime film will always be one of my favorite aspects of such movies.
Specifically, there are certain scenes where you're given insight into Deckard's character and his biting wit, thus enriching the film. In one scene - while Deckard is searching a suspect's residence - the narration provides his reasoning for centering on 2 specific evidentiary finds, his thoughts on them, why he finds them so intriguing and why they become so important as the film advances. Now imagine his thoughts being taken out of the film. I know some may disagree, but I still say it lessens Scott's film overall.
Scott is terribly off by constantly editing this aspect out of the film. I honestly don't care what his reasons are, it still seriously detracts from a great film, which is why I give his "Final Cut" 3-stars instead of 5. Is it still a terrific crime drama? Of course, but why Scott wishes to subtract from it is beyond me. Even the added scenes and spoken lines by certain characters doesn't make up for the absence of Deckard's narration.

More like Bladewalker, this movie's pace made it unfit for viewing by my impatient teenage self when it first made it to HBO in the early days of cable TV and that opinion holds. The theatrical release was infamous for its dumbed down mansplaining voiceover and tacked on happy ending, so we gave this supposedly definitive 2007 re-edit a go. The voiceover is gone but this movie is still a bore. It reminds me of the terrible '70s show Bigfoot & Wildboy. In that low-budget travesty, much time is devoted to moving the characters from one location to another. Likewise this film asks viewer repeatedly to sit back and enjoy the scenery like a jetlagged tourist in a sky gondola as our jaded hero gets from here to there. Perhaps cutting edge at the time, the set design is less rich than that found in average video games today. Harrison Ford is a lifeless cipher whose idea of acting is looking confused by letting his mouth hang open. The film scores points for atmosphere and the testing scenes are gripping but the action and violence is typical Hollywood. Loses a star due to hackneyed and intrusive Vangelis soundtrack--which in one scene inexplicably drowns out an on-screen piano. Overrated waste of time though Daryl Hannah shines as a wiley fleshbot femme fatale.

Sorry.  I didn't like this movie much.  Too dark, too dated, too slow.  Why was everyone always sweating?  The Replicants were super strong but couldn't kill Decker with their bare hands?!  The Replicants were super smart but didn't figure out how to use weapons?  The Blade Runners had to use a special machine and  interrogation to sniff out a Replicant from a human - meanwhile their eyes shimmer with a reflective shine most of the time? This is my favorite version of this Futurist masterpiece. I bought it on DVD because it was the only way I could get it without all the other versions. I loathe the Final Cut version. Redundant scenes, extended explicit and graphic scenes and relevant elements removed...horrible. It is an example of an artist (Ridley Scott) compromising his work for profit. Sean Young herself has stated how embarrassing and distressing the sex scene was involving Rachael and Deckard. Very unnecessary scene, as is the additional violence. A Masterpiece is a Masterpiece, it NEVER needs updated or improved. It is truly a fascinating film and becomes more prophetic with time. The Syd Mead visuals are still influencing everything. The last great Futurist vision before CGI and apathy...

I have two beefs with this flick. The first is: if these Replicants are going to die anyway why do they need to be assassinated?? All they'd have to do is provide protection for the key people who made them and wait for the inevitable. Second: they changed the ending! I saw the original film in a drive-in theatre back in 1982! And there was never any thought of Decker possibly being a 'Replicant' himself! He doesn't  _HAVE_  to be a Replicant to have the hots for Rachel! She's hot no matter what!! Other than that I absolutely adore Roy Batty's death scene, which was played by Rutger Hauer. His line, (paraphrase) "All those moments will be lost in time . . . like tears in the rain." was just exquisite! This movie is one of my all-time faves.

Without out doubt, the best film, story, directing, acting and concept I have seen out of Hollywood. It has incredible social depth, the issue of artificial intelligence as a sentient being  with emotions like humans have worthy, or not, of respect, rights and a place in society, and the possible future we face as a society.
This set includes fantastic out takes that take us on an in depth, behind the scenes tour of real film magic looks like the passion and genius of great team work. From the smallest detail to the grand view, from the actors perspectives to the etching of miniatures, all covered in smoke and fog, it is an incredible force. The magical collaboration of Ridley Scott, Vangellis, Fancher & Peoples, the acting team and crew, is unsurpassed.
For the Sci-Fi film fan, this is a pinnacle, like Kubrick's 2001: A Space Odyssey,  are all measured.

Either you love this cult classic, or you don't.  In a period when science fiction was treated as a simple-minded western with machines instead of horses (Star Wars comes readily to mind) this intelligent, thoughtful film based on the book by a major writer of science fiction, Phillip Dick, is thoughtful and thought-provoking.  And dark.  Very dark; the sun never appears in what seems to be a nightmare world of impossible high-rises, squalid streets, abandoned buildings and blinding artificial lights that leave the surroundings even darker and more impenetrable. Harrison Ford does well, as does a young Sean Young, but the film to me, belongs to Rutger Hauer as the embittered replicant.
More than a reasonable person needs to know. but I am not reasonable. If you've read this far, this is a rave.

To anyone who has ever obsessed over the cyberpunk genre at some point in their life (three of my favourite video games - Snatcher, Rise of the Dragon, and Shadowrun - owe their lives), Ridley Scott's dark future-noir is a revelation; the Holy Grail, Dr. Jones. The sum of its parts - gritty ambience, deep existential pondering, strange walls of light, Vangelis' brilliantly haunting and deeply effective score, Rick Deckard (Han who...?) and Roy Batty's (whose improvised closing monologue is certainly more human than human) Dark Knight/Joker dynamic - creates a synergy unmatched by any other contender in the sci-fi battle royale. So which, you ask, is the definitive of the five(!) versions? The truth is they're each remarkable in their own unique way (I prefer the Workprint, personally) and debating which one is crme de la crme is all part of the electric (sheep?) joy of Blade Runner.

Excellent packaging and quality for the price. What's in a title?  Quantum physics explains the power of this one.  When Ridley Scott chose to name his filmed adaptation of Philip K. Dick's Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep? after an unrelated novel, Alan E. Nourse's The Bladerunner, an "entanglement" was created.  Imagine a string connecting the two Blade Runners, transcending the Meaning-Context Perimeters of each work.  (In our diagram, the perimeters deliberately resemble Morse code, because beyond a literary work's context, meanings tend toward the cryptic and secret.)  That entangling string is vibrated or "enlivened" by the Meaning-Context Perimeters, very much like the string of a violin activated by a bow.  We see that the resulting resonance is interpenetrating  each work becomes colored by the other.  The significance is quasi-magical, as readers unfamiliar with Nourse's coinage of Bladerunner are yet taken by the word's glamour in Scott's usage (in its original sense, "glamour" meant enchantment/magic and was an alteration of the word "grammar").  And vice versa, since the entangling string connects beyond time.  Each title is powerful in its respective year (1974 for Nourse, 1982 for Scott) because of that entangling string; in other words, the punch of Nourse's title is in anticipation of Scott's echo of it eight years later, and, paradoxically, Scott banked on the glamour "previously" inherent in Nourse's term.  (We of course recall that in terms of quantum physics, time does not exist in the way that we observe and metabolize it.)

I find Blade Runner (1982) to be a rather unique science fiction movie in that it takes place in Los Angeles in the year 2019.  Harrison Ford starred in this movie in between starring in The Empire Strikes Back (1980) and Return Of The Jedi (1983).  This movie also stars Sean Young as Rachael, the romantic interest of Deckard (Harrison Ford).  Sometimes she looks like and reminds me of Joan Crawford from the early 1940s, mainly because of her wardrobe and shoulder pads and even her hairstyle to some extent (and that cigarette).  Anyway, she gives a good performance, as does Ford.  It also stars Rutger Hauer, Edward James Olmos, and Daryl Hannah.  This movie drags a little at times, but the action more than makes up for it.  I think maybe Christopher Nolan (director of the Batman movies from 2005, 2008, and 2012) was inspired by this movie (could be wrong) when it comes to the flying vehicle, which reminds me of Batman's flying car in The Dark Knight Rises (2012).

While this movie doesn't exactly reflect what life and reality is like in the current day (2010s), it definitely was an ambitious project that is worth seeing.  I think this movie might be an acquired taste for some people.  This review is of the director's cut DVD from 1999.  This movie was directed by Ridley Scott.

"Blade Runner : The Final Cut" is the DVD or Blu-ray version you want, rather than "Director's Cut", because of huge technical improvements to "Final Cut" in both picture quality and audio. "Director's Cut" is an early DVD, when DVD was still a new format. Disc differences between the two are severe and very noticeable. Additionally: No doubt about Deckart's human or replicant "status" after watching this "Final Cut" version.

Ask anyone who's seen Blade Runner and they'll all say the same thing:  Theatrical cut is terrible, director's cut is great, the Final Cut is amazing!  With this set, you get every cut of the film that's ever been made, including all of the special features and documentaries.  If you are a Blade Runner fan or just a sci-fi fan in general, this Blu Ray is well worth the money to buy.

The best thing about this set, as a Blade Runner fan, are the extras.  The featurettes and making of documentaries are extremely interesting and delve deep into the production.  Coupled with this is an attached booklet of production art, script pages, and pictures.

If you're looking for the absolute best home release version of this movie, this is the one you want to get!

"Blade Runner," the film (and different edits of the film) may well be the greatest science fiction film ever. Based on Phillip Dick's "When Androids Dream Do They Dream of Electric Sheep" (if a bit off, it was about 35 years ago that I read this), in this film, is brilliantly adapted. As "urban legend" has it, Author Dick really liked it. But, I hope you read the written piece, as the film, though at times troubling, does not touch the angst in the written original. For one, it omits the second story line of a new religion, and for another, makes "Rachel" even more heart-breaking. . . . I believe I have watched all edits. I like this and the original release best. The original voice-overs by Harrison Ford are "noir" at its best. This edit, truer to Mr. Dick's "Androids," is more haunting and revealing, and as such is closer to the original. Seeing, at Amazon Streaming, "The Man in the High Castle," I believe a gifted producer and director will take the challenge and attempt a version closer to the original writing (as "High Castle," so far seems true to the book). All this written, my 5-star rating is deserved. It is superior.

Well I realize that the film is almost 34 years old.  I read an appraisal recently from a very reliable, intelligent film reviewer that the Final Cut was scrubbed and cleaned but I saw no evidence of that except in select long shots.  And of course the end titles were new so they looked sharp indeed.  But the rest of the film on Blu-ray, sadly, looked no better than the VHS tape version that I played to death for many years.  I could not sense any improvements in sound either, except for more sharpness in the rain effects.

Was it worth the $13.89 for three Blu-ray discs of a fantastic film?  Yes absolutely and this should be the permanent, long-lasting copy of a great film.  Is it any better than my old VHS tape?  Nope.

In case you are interested, there are no chapter stops.  This was not important to me, but to really study the film I think the director should have provided them.  I am less likely to watch the film knowing there is no chapter menu, even if I don't ordinarily utilize them.  I cant really estimate when the last time I watched this movie was  (17 years sounds about right)  and I won't be in any rush to watch it again, based on this disappointing Blu-ray experience.

The influence of "Blade Runner" on the science fiction films which followed it cannot be over-emphasized.  Its depiction of a crowded, frenetic future Los Angeles, at once high-tech and grimy, managed to straddle the line between surreal and familiar.  The overall look is dark, with poorly-lit interiors, and exterior shots taking place mostly at night and in the rain, but the scenes are full of clearly resolved details that somehow never descend into chaos or meaningless clutter.  Harrison Ford's reluctant cop (basically an assassin) is perfect for him, although not as likeable as his Indiana Jones or even Han Solo characters.  Rutger Hauer is also perfectly cast as the Replicant leader, although this must have been for his appearance and not his acting abilities; Hauer has a resume as long as a giant squid's tentacles, but other than here and a handful of minor roles in "Buffy," "Batman Begins," and a few others, he hadn't been in anything I'd ever heard of.  The two female leads, Daryl Hannah (at one time, "the most beautiful woman in the world") and Sean Young (who?) phone in their performances, not much of a loss as their characters are supposed to be androids.  For some reason, male replicants are capable of emotion, but females aren't.  And I'm not sure what purpose the Edward James Olmos character served, other than the admittedly cool detail of leaving small origami sculptures everywhere, and delivering the immortal line "It's too bad she won't live! But then again, who does?"  Deep, man.

The plot is inconsistent to the point of absurdity.  Androids have been invented and were used for slave labor, until a few of them rebelled, so an elite team of assassins ("Blade Runners") is dispatched to eliminate them.  The fact that if this happened in real life, it would be a crisis the likes of which humanity has not seen before, and would be handled by the military as every slave revolt in history has been, is inconvenient and apparently not as interesting as the last Blade Runner hunting down the last replicants.  Along the way, we meet an anti-social maker of audio-animatronic robots, a super-rich mad scientist who no one holds accountable for the colossal screw-up of creating rebellious androids, and a skull-crushing sequence that was done far better in the "Game of Thrones" episode "The Mountain and the Viper."  I saw "Blade Runner" when it first came out, and while I remembered the line "the light that burns twice as bright burns half as long," I didn't recall the thumbs-in-the-eyes scene a few moments later, but I'll remember Hafr Jlus Bjrnsson exploding Pedro Pascal's cranium with his bare hands until the day I die.

However, the film's overarching theme of what it means to be human transcends these objections, and the film's set design alone destines it for immortality.
