Blade Runner is widely considered to be the best Science Fiction movie ever made. It is on almost every top 100 list, and that's why I am reviewing it. To tell you why it is one of the most overrated films of all time. Science Fiction is my favorite genre, and the author of Blade Runner, Philip K. Dick is one of my favorite authors, but Blade Runner is far from his best work. I would go as far as saying that Blade Runner isn't even in his top ten, and if it wasn't for Ridley Scott, it wouldn't have been the first film adaptation of Dick's work. At the time, the special effects were innovative and exciting, but they fail to live up to today's standards. With that being said, all that's left over is a simple story that follows a futuristic police chase and a very cheesy, awkward, love story. In a futuristic Los Angeles, android technology has been perfected. These replicants are used for labor an odd jobs, but occasionally, they become aware and try to run for their freedom. That is when the blade runners are called in to eliminate them. The best Blade Runner around is Deckard (Harrison Ford), a man who doesn't love his job, but always gives one hundred and ten percent. After three replicants escape from the moon, Deckard is called in to track them down and this is the whole premise of the movie. There isn't much of a side story and the rare breaks in the action, rarely prove to be substantive. The film is just you're typical chase with some very weird elements. For example, why does Rutger Hauer take off all his cloths before he fights Harrison Ford, and for that matter, what the hell is he talking about the whole time? How about the talking toys, can you tell me they weren't just a bit creepy and out of character for the rest of the film? Finally, we're in Los Angeles, why is everything Chinese? The story is just a very strange chase through a futuristic nightmare scenario for Los Angeles. Yes, Harrison Ford was terrific, and yes, it must of been the hardest thing Ridley Scott ever had to direct, but the film and story itself are very simplistic and certainly not worthy of legendary status. I love Philip K. Dick and I am obsessed with Science Fiction, but watching Blade Runner for the third time, I was still just as bored and confused as I was the other two times I saw it. How can anything that makes a person feel that way be considered legendary?

An excellent overall package and good value. While I already had the Final Cut on Blu and the 1991 variant brought to market in the early days of dvd, this was a compelling all-in-one offering. It includes the oft-maligned original theatrical cut with the narration voice-over, something I like to have around for nostalgia value if nothing else.

The "book" format of this collection includes a pleasing collection of set photos and concept art within the case. While not a priority, these "book" format blu-ray offerings can be neat. Others I've picked up here and there include those for Clash of the Titans ('81) and King Kong ('33).

Having flopped in 1982, Blade Runner took years to find an audience, and to find itself  this Final Cut from 2007 supersedes an earlier Directors Cut, cleaning up assorted blips (verbal, visual) in addition to stripping the tacked-on voiceover and dopey happy ending which marred the original release. Back on the big screen, Blade Runner remains an overwhelming experience, with Doug Trumbulls photographic effects and Larry Paulls production designs melding seamlessly with location shots of downtown LA to create a groundbreaking retro-fitted future. Vangeliss glistening score is all landscape synths, tingling strings and yearning romantic melodies, while Syd Meads vehicles drive the action delightfully. But in the end Hauers eyes have it  gazing into a future already lost in the past; shimmering, piercing, undying.

Also, it's depiction of LA in 2019 (not that far away now in 2015) seemed weird even for a sci-fi film. If you want to watch a philosophical sci-fi movie with a little bit of action this fit's the bill, but if you're looking for something more action packed watch something else.

This is from the mind of a brilliant writer, Philip K. Dick (the genius behind Minority Report, The Man in the High Castle, A Scanner Darkly, Paychecks, The Adjustment Bureau, Total Recall, Screamers...), as visualized by well-known film maker, Ridley Scott. It's a dark future in LA, and robots who appear completely human (known as replicants), but are used for slave labor in off-world colonies, tend to rebel, at times. And that's where a "blade runner" (a government-sanctioned, robot-killing cop) comes in. Harrison Ford famously portrays "Rick Deckard", who is called in (more like forced) when a half-dozen replicants come back to Earth, leaving a trail of dead humans on the way. Why have they returned? In the process of killing them (known as "retirement"), Deckard will find out more about himself than he bargained, and begin to question many things. There are great depictions of future buildings, very well-played characters, a wonderful soundtrack (by Vangelis), and a haunting movie that you won't soon forget. Considering that it was released in 1982, the work is extraordinary. Enjoy.

It's interesting how Blade is also the name of the avatar William Hunter in the 1990's Sega CD game Rise of the Dragon. It's about a cop who specializes in hunting down robots that have escaped from the slavery they were created for.  Along the way he meets a robot who didn't know she was a robot, and begins to wonder if perhaps hunting down robots is such a wonderful thing.

This film is maddening in the sense that it is brilliant in some ways, but very weak in others.  For example, the ultimate arc of the plotline consists of the good guy hunting down a group of bad guys one by one, with a romantic subplot.  This is not new.  Also, Rutger Hauer turns in what I could only call the textbook definition of over-acting.  Literally every word that comes out of his mouth is just way, way overdone.  I can't believe the director never told him to take it easy at least once.  I also felt like the majority of the plotline was extremely predictable.

On the other hand, the visuals of this film are amongst the best ever captured on film.  The set design, the use of color, lighting, and sound to create this ultra-modern world of decay (and near constant rain) is incredibly well done.

When "Blade Runner" was released in the Summer of 1982, mainstream audiences were not quite ready for this very different vision of the future. And I will even admit, I was among them at the time. I didn't understand the depth of "Blade Runner" until I had had subsequent multiple experiences of it. I don't know if you really see Blade Runner as much as become absorbed into it. Although Blade Runner was a box office disappointment upon its release, it had stiff competition in 1982. Spielberg's "ET", the sentimental science fiction film, had broken all box office records; Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan, was the favorite for pure good guy versus bad guy SF; and other films outside the genre were much more uplifting and linear, such as "Tootsie" and "An Officer and a Gentleman". (The other under-appreciated masterpiece of that year was "Sophie's Choice", although Meryl Streep did deservedly win for Best Actress.)

Despite its mixed critical reception, including a very ambivalent review by Roger Ebert who called it a "failure as a story", "Blade Runner" has emerged as one the three best films of 1982, the other two being "Ghandhi" and "Sophie's Choice". My revised list of Best Picture nominees in alphabetical order for 1982: "Blade Runner", "E.T." "Ghandhi", "Missing", "Sophie's Choice". I would still give top award nods to Ghandhi but only by the slimmest of margins. Blade Runner would be my very close second choice. ("The Verdict" and "Tootsie" are good films but not exactly masterpieces.)

The story concerns relatively new technology: the producing of humanoid cyborgs which have become dangerously close to human life. They are called "Replicants". The latest models appear to have feelings and emotions like humans. Now, some renegade Replicants who feel they were treated as slaves on a labor planet have sprung from their "slavery" and returned to earth. They wish to confront their creators. Richard "Rick" Deckard (Harrison Ford) is a "blade runner", a kind of detective/police officer who finds and exterminates renegade Replicants. One of his tools is a series of questions offered a suspected Replicant designed to create responses which tip-off the questioner as to whether or not the participant is human. But then Decker falls for a female Replicant, Rachel (Sean Young) who seems all too human.

In the 1950's and 1960's, a very select group of eclectic readers absorbed and appreciated the work of a somewhat lesser-known science fiction writer, Philip K. Dick. Dick was a maverick of the SF genre, essentially immersing readers into a world much more reminiscent of the works of Raymond Chandler and Dashiel Hammett than Gene Roddenbery or George Lucas. Philip Marlowe and Sam Spade could navigate Blade Runner's darkened and misty streets much more effectively than either James T. Kirk or Luke Skywalker. While the most popular writers of the SF genre were still getting into rocket ships and flying to planets for high adventure, Dick was painting on an entirely new canvas, where urban noir meets future technology. Flying taxis and large plasma screens reside along with overpopulation and dirty streets. And he was writing in the 1950's and 1960's! However, even by 1982, audiences were still craving the likes of heroic science fiction such as Star Trek and Star Wars. Typical audience sensibility was still far behind "Blade Runner".

What made "Blade Runner" tough on audiences at the time of its release and so appreciated today is that it challenges viewers' perceptions of not only the future but the nature of modern reality itself. Unlike Star Wars and Star Trek, "Blade Runner" is a cautionary tale, an updated version of "Frankenstein: The Modern Prometheus" and therefore, everything presented in its world is at the very least disconcerting and at the worst quite horrifying. SF has been predominantly about Utopias. "Blade Runner" is a story set in a "Dystopia". SF most often distinguishes between right and wrong, good and bad. "Blade Runner" is about the blurry shades between ethics and justice, where the ones with which we most empathize are outlaws. SF endings are often neat and tidy. "Blade Runner" offers a very ambiguous and contemplative ending (and I am not referring to the final coda of the original theatrical release). "Blade Runner" deals with themes concerning the larger questions of life and meaning, very uncommon in SF cinema as a whole. And that's why "Blade Runner" has become not only an iconic classic of the SF genre, it is one of the reasons that cinema has continued to be a captivating medium. "Blade Runner" is in the same company as "Ghandhi", "Citizen Kane", and "Casablanca". Know that SF can sometimes transcend its own genre, and BR inspired a new wave of films, such as "The Matrix" and "Dark City". "Blade Runner" was and is one of the finest examples of watershed ground-breaking cinema.

Man...Blade Runner is an amazing Film. Just had to get that out of the way. Now Ive owned the 4 disc dvd box set and have done a great deal of research into the different cuts and releases of this movie and have to say the Blu Ray release REALLY is the way to go. I features the Theatrical Cut, The International Cut, The Directors Cut and the Final Cut. But The Blu ray Set includes the WORK PRINT! I must admit i scoured a few torrent sites to find a copy, but none were seeding so...The work print is the version first previewed March 5, Continental Theater, Denver; March 6, Northpark Theatre, Dallas, 1982. The differences in this version include-Violence of the international cut (Intact), No Voice Overs-minus towards the end in the Dove scene (I'm calling it that to not ruin the ending...Nice huh?), There are other interesting variations that i can't begin to list but a huge difference is in the score. During the Bar scene a Brian Eno/David byrne track QURAN which was deleted from the Ghosts LP (as we'll as subsequent released versions of the film) over being too controversial.  I cant say if the controversy over it's release had to do with excising it from the film but i can say it works really well during that scene, Fits right in with the Vangelis compositions. But seriously....Why buy the dvd set when it doesnt even have all the versions when you can get the GLORIOUS HD BLU RAYS and the BRILLIANT WORKPRINT! It's a no brainer.

Blade Runner (1982) is the type of movie in which you really wonder what genre it belongs to. There's action, suspense, horror, sci-fi, drama, neo-noir, etc. The neo-noir is futuristic, and arguably is its genre. Then again, there's a lot of sci-fi that dominates a lot of scenes. I guess we can say that Blade Runner is a little bit of everything. Romantic music playing in intimate scenes? Of course, but this is the run-of-the-mill, typical music that we hear in dramas. Now, for the Harrison Ford casting: was he cast for this movie simply to boost ticket sales? He seems oddly out of place in this movie, and seems to just be going through the motions. His performance was nothing to brag about. This movie suffers from an identity crisis, yet that's probably what makes it appealing to the masses. Blade Runner is like one of those songs that doesn't fit a certain genre, or one that never finds its groove and momentum. Again, even more reason to like it? I think that Ridley Scott did a superb job depicting a dark and dreary world where danger lurks nearby, while giving a nice dose of tech eye candy here and there. Blade Runner is an acquired taste; perhaps I might add a star to this review at a later date. For right now, it's a good to very good action/sci-fi/drama/horror/thriller of a movie. Update (7-14-15): I now give Blade Runner five stars, and Harrison Ford's acting and place in this movie is starting to resonate. I guess that this movie needs repeated viewings until it grows on a person. If you stay with it, it'll reward you. Slow a lot of the time, it's still powerful in aesthetic, music, and plot. The characters portrayed by Rutger Hauer and Darryl Hannah are believable, and add flair to the plot, as their characters depict passion and  have a sense of mission and outcome. Update (2-10-16): I have since purchased the blu-ray that contains 4 versions of the movie, including The Final Cut. All I can say is WOW!!!! If you were impressed with The Director's Cut on regular DVD, then you will be blown away by the blu-ray. This has to be one of the best transfers ever, as the picture and sound are of the utmost pristine quality. It looks and even feels like a brand new experience. If you were ambivalent about Blade Runner in the past, you may want to purchase the blu-ray, and perhaps see it in a different light. The blu-ray release is so powerful and effective in depicting the strange world that is Blade Runner. Am I done? No way! The blu ray set includes three versions of this masterpiece (Original Cut, International Cut, and the Final cut), as well as extensive special features that'll keep you entertained for a long time. If you're looking for an all-encompassing blu ray experience that's a can't-miss, then the Blade Runner blu ray is the one. I praise director Ridley Scott for taking the time to perfect this film, while keeping an open mind along the way. I highly recommend this blu ray version of one of the most important films ever made.

Oh Geez where to start with Blade Runner? Ok so let's go by parts. Visually the film is very interesting and ahead of its time I guess based on the idea of the flying cars and the travel to another world out of earth and the use of robots, and the creation of a whole nother Earth. I have to give the movie props because anyone who can create an entire world, like we have seen with Avatar and all those Battlestar Galactica movies, deserves all the praise they can be given. I guess I just don't understand why it's such a gloomy place and that drove me insane. Yes, the neo- noir or film noir aspect of it clicks in and the camera angles and the shadows play a part but it was distracting and honestly, it made me reject that aspect of the movie. That being said, the characters in the movie were not my favorite either. I couldn't find a connection with them, neither the replicants nor the humans.  I think the movie tried to hard to make the audience feel something and leave the movie with some sort of thought of wisdom about humanity and how long we have to live and how much the replicants were like humans or even more human than the humans and to some point it succeeded cause here we are discussing it but towards the end it became ridiculous like that fight scene between Roy and Deckard. I guess what confused me the most was the "love" story between Rachel and Deckard. Again, here is Deckard killing all the replicants, who were in their turn killing because they wanted to feel human, but suddenly he gets to Rachel and not only is she a replicant but she is a replicant with an unspecified time to live so that they are able to escape this disaster of a world they live in and fly out to the mountains where nothing has been touched or changed. In conclusion, I can appreciate the creation of the visual world and style and transportation to another time aspect of the movie. What I do not appreciate is a sentiment of the world has gone to hell and every body is shooting at each other in the middle of the street for an hour and forty minutes and then all of a sudden the guy gets the girl and they live happily ever after in what seems to be a pre- blade runner world. It seems like two movies to me. Plus the romance between Rachel and Deckard was more forced by Deckard than by Rachel's choice. The girl only wanted to know whether she was human or replicant, Deckard, not run away with you.

The extras are an amazing insight into how the film was restored and how some of the glaring problems were fixed (the scene where Zora is 'retired' and it is obviosuly a stunt woman, the horrible ADR inside the reptile seller's shop and the releasing of the dove at the end).  Otherwise the film was cleaned up and brightened to reveal all of the details in the amazing world Scott and his team created.  For those of us that grew up watching this on VHS it is nothing short of a revelation to see this gorgeous version.

Each version of Bladerunner has its particular qualities and adherents and the debates have gone on for years. For me, this version is the best, embodying Ridley Scotts final vision for his film.

Bladerunner is a landmark in cinema, not merely in science-fiction film. The depth and richness mean you can watch it over and over, relish the many articles and studies that have been produced and participate in online discussions. An entire culture has grown up around a film that suffered from studio butchery and cowardice and then from critical negligence, to become an acknowledged masterpiece. The film has entered modern consciousness and continues to garner fans and students.

Aesthetically, philosophically, viscerally, Bladerunner rewards repeated viewings. If you must have one copy, this is it; but do yourself a favour and purchase them all.

Finally, some thirty-three years after its release, I sat down and watched "Blade Runner." Not "this cut, that cut, or whatever-in-the-hell cut"  Blade Runner "Groupies" extoll.....No. I watched one cut only....i.e., the aptly named "Happy Ending" cut, in which Rick and Rachel drive off into sunset together. Ummmmm...... errrrrrrrr...."Masterpiece?" Nope, not at all. Not even close. Rather, this weak and lame, "Ray Bradburry Wanna Be" cautionary tale of the rapidly approaching future is a visually driven, overinflated and hyperbolic result of what happens when Ridley Scott is given a lot of money to play with. The characters are one-dimensional, cardboard cut-outs....with cinematic emotions running the gamete from A to B. Scott went so nutso- crazy with visuals- he forgot the fine art of character development. And so I yawned....neither mesmerized nor entranced. I was bored. Completely, totally bored. I just didn't give a damn.....about any character or their ultimate fate(s). A plate of vanilla sugar cookies holds more interest. Perhaps I'm a tad jaded. Perhaps because I'm a Broadcast Producer and zeroed in on the Special Effects within seconds, I saw that Scott was planning a visual "Holy Grail" to Blue Screen, Miniatures, early CJE, ADO upon ADO and the obligatory "Wetted Down" Set(s).....replete with the oh so predictable menacing combination of smoke, fog, darkness and piercing neon. Yup. That about sums it up. Take away Scott's "Whiz Bang" SFX budget-and you're left with a dull film replete with dull characters.

One of the best movies ever made regardless of genre. Nearly perfect in every aspect and one of the rare times a writer's work is actually enhanced by the film based upon it.  Philip K. Dick's original short story and novel were as terrific as most of his work (I started reading science fiction around age 10 and he became one of my favorite authors over the years). I think the essence of the themes this movie addresses are actually more fully realized in the film, a rare thing indeed. (Yes, many of the novel's themes are not present, the film chooses to focus on a few specific ones, instead, but that's fine with me.) It's a movie that has never left me since my first viewing and I have watched it so many times since and thought about it often over the years. A true treat and a great work of art. Enjoy it, as it is an exceptional experience.

"I've never paid quite so much attention to a movie, ever. But we had to create a world that supported the story's premise, made it believable. Why do you watch a film seven times? Because somebody's done it right and transported you to its world." -- Ridley Scott

-----
[Note: Rutger Hauer was an inspired choice, in my opinion, for the part of Roy, who's much different than Dick's original character and the thing that turns this movie into something special along with the incredible world so fully realized in the film thanks to the entire crew and the many other fine performances by all involved. Too much great direction and acting to discuss here, and great score, art, effects, etc. all much discussed elsewhere.]
-----
P.S. And hey, now you can actually buy a Nexus 6, how cool is that?  :-)  (Yes, Serenity reference intended, links two of my favorite SF films. <g>)
love it

Disc 2, Dangerous Days, Making Blade Runner. Documentary of the making of Blade Runner, very specific and varied commentary with detail, worth a Toblerone Bar. (When I wrote this, I never thought anyone would find it helpful >V<, guess I might have a chance as a Hollywood Madame smile -).

DISC 1 3 commentaries. 1) Ridley Scott, a commentary I abandoned as Mr. Scott continually excused and justified his actions in the making of the film. Although, I had read about problems on the set, until hearing this I could not imagine how bad they must have been. Apparently, all of his actions should be unquestionable, because he was the one being paid. Like Speilberg and other directors who knew what they were doing, the fact that he was the one paid to do the job justified any of his actions. That statement could use some finessing. I've turned down "payment" and jobs in the past made to me because of how I can creatively manipulate appearances, much like a director. Had I taken them I would have been the town whore, somewhat like Mister Scott.

Superman never made any money For saving the world from Solomon Grundy And sometimes I despair the world will never see Another man like him. Lyrics, Crash Test Dummies (1991)

Not that I'm writing in support of Speilberg, because he has become the town whore as of late, but at very least he motivated much stronger storytelling with fewer resources in his first efforts.

2) The writer's commentary, snore. I would revisit this some other time.

3) The real reason for filmmakers to rent or buy this DVD: Commentary by Visual Futurist Syd Mead, Production Designer Lawrence G. Paull, Art Director David Snyder and Special Photographic Effects Supervisors Douglas Trumbull, Richard Yuricich and David Dryer. As a film done with in camera effects this group of people offer invaluable information. Small details with comments on how and why certain in camera effects were used. There is also an attitude of mutual respect amongst this group of artists (that is certainly nothing I've ever heard amongst cameramen, where backstabbing is common).

Blade Runner is like fine leather. It luxurious compared to it's contemporaries and most importantly, it gets better with age. 30 years on and Blade Runner stands the test of time, continuing to influence all forms of media from comics, to games, to still more movies. What Blade Runner excels at it it's ability to create a fully realized world that is familiar and exotic at the same time. What guides the harsh newness of the futuristic setting is humanity's ability to adapt and change with it- this is manifested in the main character, Deckard. Expertly played by Ford, he is our connection to this new world we are thrown into. He's the human we know, uneasy with replicants, and a strong sense of self. Mostly. You see, both of these elements are established in the film at various points, but by the end of the film, they both come tumbling down. We end up understanding why replicants are the way they are, and we see Deckard in a much different light. In this way, we've proven our very human ability to adapt again and again.

Wow this movie is a weird one, but also very entertaining if you are a fan of the sci fi action adventure genre.

 The movie is based on the book, "Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?" by sci fi author Philip K. Dick.  The story explores what does it mean to be human.

 I am a big fan of actor Harrison Ford, and love the work he has done over the many years including "Star Wars", "Indiana Jones", "Air Force One", & "Patriot Games".  All great movies.  Actor Rutger Hauer is also fantastic too.

 Basic plot, veteran cynical detective Decker "Harrison Ford" is charged with hunting down fugitive androids who have rebelled against their programing, and escaped to Earth on their own.  His orders are to find the fugitive androids, and kill them in what he calls putting them in retirement.  The androids are exactly like humans, but much physically stronger and they only have a life span of around 4 years.

 A powerful fugitive model android in the form of actor Rutger Hauer, wants to live longer and has gone on a mission to track down his creators, as Ford pursues him running into and fighting other bizarre androids along the way.

The special effects in this movie are very spectacular for its time, and the tone and music play out like a digital slow playing jazz album.  The artistic imagery, and set scenes are both awe inspiring and also in some cases very gritty and dim.

 The first time I had seen this I was like five or six years old and remembered some scenes vividly like the flying cars, the pyramid headquarters, the Japanese Gesha images, the exotic owl, and this weird dancing lady with the android snake; then after re-watching the film many years later I had the feeling of watching a 1940's Detective film noir drama with some romance thrown in between Sean Young and Ford.

 If you like sci fi fantasy where you are taken to another weird and exotic alien world with in our own, then this movie should entertain.

The most groundbreaking film of the late 20th century. Virtually every scifi of its type since has taken inspiration and even filming techniques from this brilliant film.

Usually a director's cut is superior to the theatrical release of a film; the artist's true vision of what they wanted to say vs. what the studio told them to say to sell theatre tickets.

Sadly, this is NOT the case here. This is one of the greatest sci-fi films ever made and stands the test of time...it doesn't look or feel dated even in the year 2015.

... but without Harrison Ford's gritty narration - a burnt-out, strung-out "cop" (a legal assasin in all reality), tortured by what he does, and who he is - feeding you his sometimes insightful, sometimes bitterly callous, but always tinged with emptiness inner thoughts and inner dialogue...this movie comes up short.

Some would argue the narration "dumbs down" the movie for those too unimaginative to figure it out; however it adds a gripping, foreboding tension to the film and the ending, with the narration, is truly a spiritual moment, an epiphany for Ford's chracter.

Without the narration it leaves the movie, the moral tale of the folly of Man playing God, and the greater lesson learned by Ford's character from Rutger Hauer's chracter after Hauer spares Ford's life in the end (that ALL life is precious, even an enemy's)is lost completely, or at least in question and up to any and all personal interpretation.

I love the original theatrical version. The Director's Cut is fantastic, but I like the internal dialogue of the original.

The film itself was fine, even with the changes made that detracted from the version I saw in the theatre.  My rating is based on the very poor quality of this digital version.  Visually the film was slightly out of focus and domewhat lacking in contrast.  The most objectionable aspect, however, was the audio.  It was necessary to turn the volune on both my computer AND my hd TV up to 100% to get a minimally acceptable level.  This has been the case with the three films I've rented and the two I've purchased -- a problem I have not had with ANY of the films I've rented from the Google Play Store.

Streamed from from Prime, this version has by far the best video I've seen in several other versions of this movie, an all-time classic set in a steamy, always-raining future Los Angeles of the now-not-so far off future of 2019. This version, however, is missing the last, final scene which appears in other versions I have seen, and without it, in my opinion, the ending seems anti-climatic and unfinished: I want that ending back, so I'll keep watching the version I have on DVD even though the video is not nearly so good.

I love the film. and it fits one commentator's statement that it is a "A haunting, eerily prophetic mixture of science fiction and film noir." Set in a dystopian LA occupied mostly by Asians and over run with thieves, many of them very strange, the reality is now pretty close to the movie, watering down the effect the film used to have that it represented the future.

Still, it is a classic, and I watch it again and again if only to see Rutger Hauer's soliloquy at the end. Those lines have become a part of my spirituality, for lack of a better word: we are here, as are the androids of the film, to see things you will never see; and in my version, to carry those visions to the next world for those who have forgotten this one.

Naturally, there is a love story, a good one, and that, too, raises some interesting questions. As does the entire film.

I really like sci-fi films and I like Harrison Ford so I thought I was going to love it.  Unfortunately, this film is a slow moving attempt to recreate an classic film noir atmosphere and never quite reaches orbit.  The tech doesn't look too clunky and the special effects are few enough that it hasn't become a joke like some 80s futuristic films.  The problem is that it is way too ponderous with long stretches of Harrison Ford narrating or driving along thinking.  Most of the action scenes are him getting his brains beat in by the "Skin Jobs" and escaping death out of sheer luck, which might be what gives this film the little bit of endearing charm that it has.  The characters are all poorly developed, vapid, uninspiring, and forgettable such that you don't remember any of their names, just the outcome.

That said, its worth watching once and should be on the list of suggested films for the sci-fi aficionado.

For this review I chose to review the original theatrical cut of the classic film Blade Runner (1982).  Blade Runner stars Harrison Ford and is directed by the great Ridley Scott.  Blade Runner was Scott's third time directing a major motion picture. Despite being comparatively inexperienced, Blade Runner is one of Scott's finest films.

Blade Runner is decades ahead of its time.  Blade Runner showed several technologies that are in existence, or being developed today.  For instance in one scene a huge window transitions to a dark tint on command.  This is actually a technology that Corning is developing now.  Blade Runner showcased a payphone with two-way video technology.  While payphones are on their way out, two-way video technology comes standard on nearly every smart phone in the form of Skype.  In the film there are synthetic humans and animals created at the biological level.  Today scientists are growing tissue and organs in labs.

Overall the acting in the movie is surprisingly good for an 80's action movie.  There were a few moments where the acting was not very credible, especially one scene in which Ford's character is surprised by one of the antagonists named Leon. Ford's expression of shock and fear was so over the top it was comical.  The best acting performance in the film was given by Rutger Hauer who plays the leader of the group of replicants that Ford is hunting.  There is much of the typical 80's sinister villain in Hauer's character, but he played the part well.

The film is visually striking; the cinematography is amazing for the time.  The use of lighting and smoke to give the future a bleak appearance devoid of nature was quite impressive.  The special effects were great for a film made before personal computers were readily available.  Flying cars, massive buildings, environmental effects, etc.  I enjoyed the film greatly and look forward to watching Scott's 2007 re-cut of the film.  I give Blade Runner 5 / 5.  (Must See)

Roy Batty: "I've seen things you people wouldn't believe. Attack ships on fire off the shoulder of Orion. I've watched C-beams glitter in the dark near the Tannhauser gate. All those moments will be lost in time... like tears in the rain..." This 1982 production was Ridley Scott's first film (this third overall) after his breakout film, "Alien" in 1979. Taking a break from his Han Solo and Indiana Jones roles, Harrison Ford is perfect as the Blade Runner, Rick Deckard; and Rutger Hauer costars as the chief Replicant...it was his favorite role and probably his best. The film depicts a dystopian Los Angeles in 2019 in which genetically engineered Replicants (visually indistinguishable from adult humans), are manufactured by the powerful Tyrell Corporation. Their use on Earth is banned and Replicants are exclusively used for dangerous, menial, or leisure work on off-world colonies. Six Replicants have defied the ban and returned to Earth in an attempt to extend their short life spans. They are hunted down and "retired" by special police operatives known as Blade Runners. The plot focuses on the escaped replicants led by Roy Batty (Hauer) and the burnt-out expert Blade Runner, Rick Deckard (Ford) who reluctantly agrees to take on one more assignment to hunt them down. This is a sci/fi actioner, with awesome special effects (especially for 1982) but on many levels it is indebted to film noir conventions...the femme fatale, rainy atmospherics, dark and shadowy cinematography; and the questionable moral outlook of the hero. Speaking of special effects, my favorite is the "Spinner", the term for the flying cars used in the film, primarily by law enforcement personnel...they can be used as a ground based vehicle or a flying VTOL vehicle. In addition to Ford and Hauer, look for Sean Young, Edward James Olmos, and Daryl Hannah in key support roles. Among the best of Ridley Scott's work, it is among my favorite sci/fi films!

I finally got around to examine the 3-disc 30th Anniversary Collector's Edition, and I'm relieved that the original theatrical version(s) are available in pristine and IMHO superior quality than the "Final Cut".

Although only the "Final Cut" fixed a few production goofs by means of CGI (I never found these too bothersome) and reveals slightly better miniature photography, shadow detail is partially reduced compared to the theatrical version (e.g. Bryant's police office) and in general I found the theatrical version's original cinematography more pleasant to watch.

One of the strong suits of the film had always been how it creates "atmosphere" by means of photography, music and sound design. One of such highlights is the morning flight to the Tyrell-Corporation pyramid, but in the "Final Cut" Vangelis' beautiful score is compromised because of redundant air traffic chatter.

But this is just a somewhat logical continuation of atmosphere deconstruction, because the biggest offender - for multiple reasons - is this awful and pointless unicorn sequence Ridley Scott felt compelled in 1992 to squeeze into the film.

Supposedly, it was then to convey the impression that Gaff's unicorn Origami hinted that he knew of Deckard's dreams and one logical conclusion would have been that Deckard is a replicant, too (but doesn't explain why he doesn't have the replicants' superstrength).

One of the documentaries focuses on this particular issue and it almost seems that every VIP in Hollywood throws in his or her 0.02 $, but no one ever seems to wonder what Gaff's other origamis were supposed to hint (that Deckard rather wanted to be a chicken farmer than a cop? that he was actually gay and empty Hotel rooms gave him funny ideas?).

Always seemed to me that Gaff was making subtle symbolic and clever statements, that he considered Deckard to be a coward (chicken) or that searching other people's belongings had an exciting nature (Peeping Tom). With the unicorn being a symbol of the quest for bliss and happiness, I always felt Gaff merely understood and sympathized with Deckard's needs, adding a facet to the Gaff character that has been somewhat lost ever since 1992.

The VIPs seemed equally oblivious to Gaff's line "Too bad, she (Rachel) won't live!" Assuming Deckard was a replicant with a short life-span himself, Gaff's statement would be absolutely point- and worthless.

Now hope is a good thing and a good thing never dies, and after winding in agony listening to all this Deckard=replicant nonsense the familiar face of my favorite living filmmaker appeared on the screen and said what everybody else had obviously missed thus far: It's about a man rediscovering his humanity, if Deckard were a replicant the film wouldn't really make a lot of sense (Thank you, Frank Darabont!).

And last but not least, Harrison Ford popped up and revealed mild astonishment, making it abundantly clear that he played the character as a genuine human being, unaware of any ambiguous aspects.

Ain't that remarkable that Harrison Ford's characters are involved in what may just be as well the two dumbest revisions in film history?!?

To cut a long lamentation short: Watch the original theatrical versions first (and check out the workprint version and the deleted / alternate scenes, too), these are the original context and reason for BLADE RUNNER's ongoing appeal.

There are more than 3000+ reviews of this movie in Amazon, thus there isn't anything much left for anyone to write after 30 years, but I am bound to write a few words for a movie that to my opinion is a masterpiece in the genre.

Since my migration to the western world, I have purchased every single version of this from VHS to DVD and then Blu-ray and now I even own the digital version too.
The only thing I would say about this masterpiece by Philip K Dick is that it would not have been the same without the haunting soundtrack by Vangelis.  Especially the Love Theme which begins with Rachel playing piano and then it leads into the music.
If you are into science fiction and you like Ridley Scott then this is a must have.
Thank you Ridley and Vangelis for your collaboration on this great achievement that is truly unforgettable.

Moody, evocative, and influential, "Blade Runner" is considered to be one of the truly epochal films in the science fiction genre. A distressed, retro-future late modern aesthetic contrasts both aesthetically and philosophically with the kind of clean, sterile classic modernism found in Stanley Kubrick's "2001: A Space Odyssey." If "Star Wars" inhabits a worn universe then "Blade Runner" occupies a broken down universe.

"Blade Runner" attempts to be a kind of neo-noir film, filled with many of the tropes of that genre: the world-weary detective, the femme fatale, the dark, seedy underside of society as a backdrop, etc. The engine that makes noir films go is a combination of plot twists and chemistry between the detective and the femme fatale. Unfortunately, "Blade Runner" falls short in both categories. The story is thin, stretched over the film's run time, and far too linear. "Blade Runner" has been lauded for being philosophical and enigmatic, but this must surely be due to projection by fans and critics. The lack of story makes the film inscrutable.

Likewise, Harrison Ford and Sean Young don't have a great deal of chemistry, primarily because Ford seems to be sleep walking through the role. Perhaps this was a deliberate choice on his part, but what is presumably supposed to be read as world-weariness on the part of the character, Deckard, looks instead like reluctance on the part of the actor, Ford, to inhabit the movie.

The movie's influence on subsequent generations of filmmakers and their films cannot be denied. However, as a film "Blade Runner" is more style than substance.

This review covers "Blade Runner: The Final Cut" (although I suspect that there will never be a true final cut of this movie--Ridley Scott cannot seem to keep from tinkering with it). The quality of the transfer is not always easy to tell in a streaming version but to my eyes it looked crisp and defect free.

Five discs chock full of supplements and no less than five different cuts of the film, including the infamous "Workprint" version of the film which integrates long lost scenes only rumored about up until now. Picture and sound quality are above expectations (the audio especially; make it a point to select the DolbyTrueHD tracks in the settings before you watch) and the three hour plus making of, "Dangerous Days: Making Blade Runner" is a must watch for fans of the film, as well as film buffs, historians and students. If you've read "Future Noir: The Making of Blade Runner" by Paul M. Sammon, you'll want to tune in to his commentary on the workprint version as well, seeing as this man is probably THE authority on all things Blade Runner. Stills, galleries, archives, featurettes new and old... you absolutely cannot go wrong with this set. Ridley Scott's seminal classic gets the treatment it deserves and gets completely laid bare for you with this incisive, complete package. If you're a serious film buff and you have a nice setup at home, your collection needs this title in it, period.
This is a great Blu Ray set if you are a Blade Runner aficionado!  It has several different version film cuts!

One of the few people posting on this sight who went to the premiere in Hollywood, I found "Blade Runner" to be one of Ridley Scotts finest movies and was puzzled over his objections about final cut. So I never watched the DVD version because the rare 70mm print we saw at the premiere impressed me so much that nothing could ever take its place in my mind. Granted, this version of the future now seems silly. But back then, I fell in love with Scott's version of the Phillip K. Dick story "Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?" Both Scott and Dick posed a good question at the time - if we grow specialized "people" to do our bidding, should we consider them fully human? Since androids will never come to pass (as envisioned at least) and LA will never be a city in perpetual darkness under a din of oil companies run amok and giant pyramids with flying police cars, I believe it's safe assume the answer is redundant. Still, I love the performances and the ambience and the score of the original film. The director's cut? Not so much, especially the ending. Walk into the elevator and that's it? No, sorry, Ridley. Poor ending. Bad change to a good film that should standing on its own merits. The new cuts aren't worth your time or ours.

Maybe I need to watch it again, but based off 1 viewing, I was let down with Blade Runner. From a filmmaking standpoint, it's gorgeous, undisputably beautiful. I was impressed and shocked that this was released in the early 80s. The acting, especially by the grad replicant was especially excellent. Also the premise and world the movie takes palce in is really interesting, but the choice to focus on 4 escaped replicants wanting to meet their creator felt underwhleming. The action was OK, but slow motion was overused and some of the fight scenes were just awkward and looked goofy (specifically the acrobatic replicant fight). What really soured me on this me though was the rape scene. Even though nothing was actually shown, the scene was basically the precursor to rape. What made that scene even more egregious was the end. All in all, this is a pretty movie that had the potential to tell a much more interesting story. I've heard that this is a sci-fi classic, but I was let down. Watch Ridley Scott's Alien instead.
Harrison Ford....need I say anymore?  He is one of the best actors on this planet.

Why did they think it was better to leave out the final scene on the rail train. The over-arching principle behind the final narrative was to give us a feeling of continuity and to understand what he was thinking inside about Rachael. Because of cutting this and several other "narrative scenes" Blade Runner loses its "realism" and becomes another "artistic" campy variation of directing.

IF you want to really watch a good version of Blade Runner for you "x" generation, please get ahold of an older version of the DVD. The final scene at the train, makes it all worthwhile.

Blade Runner is a sci-fi masterpiece.  It has almost everything in a good sci-fi flick; breathtaking effects, a deep and philosophical story, good characters, amazing atmosphere, and a good cast.  Harrison Ford brings his A-game with this one.  This is probably one of my favorite performances of his.  In my opinion this is Ridley Scotts 2nd best film behind Gladiator.  However, regardless of how good it is, this is not a film I would watch all the time.  Admittedly, when I first saw this movie I hated it.  I gave the film another chance though and I grew to love it.  The reason I didn't like it at first was because I wasn't in the right mindset for it.  I was expecting a film like Star Wars which this is definitely not.  You really have to be in the right mindset to view this.  Blade Runner is not the movie you just pop in for a casual viewing to kill time or if you want to have a fun time.  Its dark, atmospheric, philosophical, and has a downbeat tone throughout.  This is most likely why Blade Runner didn't do well in the theatre.  This film came out the same year as E.T.  Everyone wanted fun sci-fi which this film clearly isnt.  Fortunately, over the years, it has become a cult classic which it deserves to be.

The film takes place in Las Angeles in the dystopian future of 2019.  We follow a retired cop named Rick Deckard (Harrison Ford) who is called back to the force temporarily.  Several human-like androids called replicants have gone rogue and it is Deckards job to bring them down.

As I said, the film looks brilliant.  I think the special effects are on-par with the Star Wars trilogy.  Yes, its not the most colorful looking film or very fun to look at, but thats the point.  The film is going for a very realistic dystopian future with overpopulation, pollution, and very cultural.  The acting is great particularly from Ford.  The only characters worth mentioning are Deckard or the main replicants, Batty (Rutger Hauer).  The story is told from their different prospectives.  From following both of them we see both of their views on what it means to be human which is one of the main themes of the movie.

There are things that can be seen as flaws with the film.  When I first saw the movie there were many things I didn't like about it until I tied to see things differently.  Firstly the film moves at a fairly slow pace or, at least, it felt that way.  This is a trait you see in most Ridley Scott films.  The atmosphere and overall feel of the film is a little too good if that makes sense.  If you are the slightest bit sleepy this film can easily put you to sleep.  I just about fell asleep on my first viewing.  Id watch the directors cut or the final cut of the film if possible.  In the theatrical cut you have Harrison Ford give narrations throughout the movie and it just made the film even more of a snore fest.  The film is trying to build atmosphere and enthrall you into the world its created, but some people will probably have issue with it.  Its not bad but I do think people will think the film is too padded-out.

Another thing is the action scenes.  The action in this film is not like Star Wars or Indiana Jones.  Deckard is actually not a very good fighter.  He gets his ass handed to him quite frequently by the replicants.  This did really bother me on first viewing.  However, I don't feel that way now.  I think that the way they did the actions scenes made them feel more real.  Besides, if they were to have Star Wars or Indiana Jones type action in this then it would conflict with the tone of the rest of the film.

Overall, Blade Runner is a classic movie that should be seen at least once.  Just go in with the mindset that this is not like Star Wars, E.T., War of The Worlds, or any of those sci-fi films and youll be fine.  Its sad that it didn't get much recognition when it was first released, but at least it is getting the treatment it deserves now.

When this came out, people thought it was kind of weird, but I liked it. I have always had the VHS, but wanted to replace that with a disc. This is a good, futuristic, science fiction movie. The subject matter is AI, and what happens to them. Also, Harrison Ford is the best at whatever he does.

... but if you are looking for a compelling and thought provoking story on so many levels, this is the film for you.  Replicants - manufactured humans who are little more than slaves, designed with limited life spans of a few years and implanted memories.  When a few of them go on an exceedingly violent rampage seeking to extend their lives, a Blade Runner, essentially a bounty hunter, is sent to exterminate them.  That's the story in a nutshell but this film is far more than that.

What becomes of my memories, feelings, and accomplishments when I die?  Will my life really matter when I'm gone and how?  How long do I have to live and why am I so powerless to change the inevitable?  This film will have you asking such questions with what is one of the most moving soliloquies of any film ever made.

There is no happy ending for this film, at least not in the conventional sense.  But you'll have a lot to think about after you've seen it and it might leave you feeling a bit uncomfortable.  Add this one to your movie bucket list.

Perhaps my favorite Science Fiction movie of all time, and top ten of any genre. Combining the grizzled narration that painted the worlds of Sam Spade and Phillip Marlowe with a vision of the future that still holds up thirty years later with few exceptions, it is both a riveting action adventure and an existential inquiry into the question of just what is life, and what gives it meaning or value. If nothing else it is worth sitting through for the final scenes in which Rutgar Hauer shines his brightest as the dying replicant faced with the decision to take or give life in his final moments of sentience.
Given how well it plays even today it's hard to believe it's been over 30 years since this movie was made.  It was and remains an exemplary example of the genre.

Even after many years, its power is undiminished. With the perspective of time, it's clear that the magic derives mostly from the visionary setting and the otherness of the replicants, especially Hauer. It's hard to imagine the movie without him. The hackneyed policeman-coming-out-of-retirement is the weakest part of the film, and Ford is the short straw acting-wise. But the twist really works, Hauer really is the center of good at the end, and that launches the viewer into a special place.

Now that I know a bit more about Dick's amphetamine habit, it's easy to understand his sympathy for the replicants. His fictional androids lived for four years, but they burned brighter than any human. Dick died of a stroke at 54 after a life on speed.

A classic yet still fresh, despite the already-hilarious 2019 card.  The noirish detective mystery in a sci-fi world is just a thin cover for its themes of mortality, humanity, morality, and the search for, or struggle against, place and purpose.  This was the Final Cut version - Harrison Ford's obviously-bored voiceover is removed and there is no resolution at the end.  Both factors means the story and the main character are far more ambiguous, which made the movie a better story for me.  The movie remains ahead of its time.  I watched this streaming thanks to Prime but the color, clarity, and sound appeared top-notch which was much appreciated for a movie set in generally dark, rainy surroundings.  Blade Runner:  The Final Cut is the rare example of a film where the director didn't insert 'upgrades' to show off but which are ultimately pointless or detrimental to the story.

Blade Runner is one of the best movies of the past century.  It outdoes any science fiction movie I've seen before or since, even though special effects may now be more sophisticated.  The setting and special effects create an Apocalyptic Earth that is believable.  This is a dark movie, of course, in tone and appearance, as it was meant to be--and can offer only a small amount of hope, both for human nature and what the future of humankind holds. It was easy for me to suspend disbelief throughout.  What I like most is that the movie is not about good humans and bad genetically-engineered people.  It reveals the deep flaws in the human characters--primarily their hardness and lack of compassion; but, more importantly, at moments, it reveals a "common humanity" shared by humans and androids, who have, over time learned to have primitive feelings.  The love story is strangely beautiful, poignant, sensual and sexual, and it brings out the best traits of the blade runner, compassion and a desire to protect. He learns from the androids, in ways, how to be more human himself.

 One of the most moving and thought-provoking scenes centers around a few lines of poetry that come, unexpectedly, from the deadliest android.  That scene has stayed with me since the first time I saw this movie in the 1990's. The motto of the company that creates the androids is "More real than real."  At the moment of the poetry, I was thinking that the androids were maybe "more human being than human being," despite their penchant to ruthlessly kill in order to survive.  But then, many humans have this same primal tendency to do whatever is necessary to survive.

The suspense and tension of the story is always tightly wound, with surprises and twists, and supported by the post-Apocalyptic setting.  Movies often foretell the future. Now genetic engineering, at least of animals, is being done, and the genetic engineering of human beings seems bound to come next.  Blade Runner brings up so many questions about who the creator/Creator is and what the creator/Creator owes to those he has created, as well as what the creator/Creator can actually give as remedy for human fears--especially the fear of ceasing to exist.

I had to buy this set to get a monologue version which was the one I first saw at the theater and loved. To me THIS is the definitive version of the film and no other will suffice. The monologue gives a Humphrey Bogart Sam Spade film Noir tone to the film and is far superior to the versions without it. The monologue tells the audience who Deckard is in the opening moments of the film.

 "They don't advertise for killers in the Newspaper. That was my job, ex - cop, ex - killer, ex - blade runner." How is the audience to supposed to understand Deckard's character without it ? The monologue puts the audience into Deckard's mind from the start.

Rutger Hauer is excellently cast as Roy Batty, the leader of the renegade replicants. He projects an aura of danger that is palpable to everyone. This is amply demonstrated in his confrontation with the genetic eye designer Chew. "Fiery the angels fell.  Deep thunder rolled around their shoulders, burning with the fires of Orc." "Questions." "... Morphology? Longevity? Incept dates?

Hannibal Chew: Don't know, I don't know such stuff. I just do eyes, ju-, ju-, just eyes... just genetic design, just eyes. You Nexus, huh? I design your eyes.

Batty: Chew, if only you could see what I've seen with your eyes!

After finding out Eldon Tyrell is the person he is looking for and that JF Sebastian can get him in to see Tyrell, Batty slowly asks Chew, who is freezing,

"Now Where... would we find..... This JF Sebastian .....?

Really liked this movie. The big Coca-Cola add on the building in the city was haunting. A good post-capitalist dystopia in which the people are poor and a large corporation de facto runs the city, the Tyrell Corp. Ford is a great character. Not altogether "good:" doesn't follow modern American Christian values, has an ambiguous romantic scene with Rachel, which comes close to him forcing her. He is not immediately likeable, but we grow to like him as we see he is authentic in an age of manufactured goods and (literally) manufactured people: he is authentically sad, he is authentically tired, authentically attracted to Rachel, in a way that is sometimes ugly but sometimes soft and lovely. Had to watch this for a theology class on the Book of Genesis, but I don't remember the context. Anyways, glad I watched.

Although when it came out there were plenty of naysayers who disliked the (apparently last-minute, I think?) voice-over narration, which I admit is a bit campy, this movie is a true classic. Its vision of a dystopian future Los Angeles where it constantly rains (I kinda wish, right about now!) and everybody still smokes cigarettes (indoors, without opening a window or asking if anyone minds!) is nonetheless compelling, and the story is good, very film-noirish, with beautiful visuals and a score by Vangelis.
Excellent!

Two parts noir thriller, one part future fiction, one part monster movie; a meditation on the quality of mercy.  Still an engaging take on the perennial SF theme of what it means to be human.  I was a little disappointed to find that the cinematography -- the famously atmospheric look and feel of the film -- did not measure up to my memory of it.  I suspect that's simply because its once-innovative expression of future L.A. has been imitated so often in the ensuing decades.  But I guess having imitators is sort of a benchmark test for "classic" status in film, and it's my view that Blade Runner deserves that status.  I have no basis to compare this "Final Cut" version to other versions.  On its own, I think it tells the tale and makes its points in a fairly seamless way.  Two days later, I'm still replaying scenes in my head.

I had high expectations for a movie lauded as one of the best science fiction movies ever. I haven't been so disappointed in a long time. The plot is murky to the point that I wasn't sure if it had advanced at all until over half the movie was gone. Pacing was way off, I can't count the number of times I was left staring at an actor waiting for the scene to change with nothing happening. The lighting was also incredibly annoying to watch. I do not enjoy being strobed by lights in the background, even if for dramatic effect. One aspect I did appreciate was the topic of replicants, but I did not think the movie fully capitalized on this at all. Overall I would rank this movie in the same realm as other B list science fiction movies.

Classic Sci-Fi in all of it's glory, starring a young 'Han Solo' era Harrison Ford, Rutger Hauer, Darryl Hannah and Sean Young.  In 2019, the Earth is being infiltrated by a small band of replicants - Identical to Humans in virtually every way, but developed to be used as slave labor off world.

The only thing that distinguishes replicants from actual people is that they are activated without any emotions of their own (although their creators believe that they will develop them on their own), and a built in fail safe in case something goes wrong with the replicant >>  They only have a four year lifespan.  One thing is sure...  judging by the behavior of 'Roy', the murderous replicant played by Rutger Hauer, it's possible for them to go insane, and it's up to Blade Runner Harrison Ford to hunt them down.

The visual effects are state of the art for the time - no CGI here boys and girls - but they look great and hold up well.

Like Walt Whitman who revised Leaves of Grass until he reached the last page on his deathbed, Ridley Scott has been tinkering with his classic Blade Runner.

After various Directors Cuts, Scott has gone the butcher shop by coming up with chopped liver and Salisbury steaks. He has swept up the bits from the cutting room floor and installed them in the butchers window.

We finally got around to seeing the 2007 Blade Runner: The Final Cut.

If we settle upon this one as the cut above the rest, wed be rejecting all those versions that made 1982s Blade Runner one of the most mind-boggling and influential movies of its time.

Two movies changed the sci-fi landscape forever: Mad Max and Blade Runner. They made the future ugly and dirty, crowded and unpleasant. Throw in Alien (also by Scott) and you have a futuristic mess.

No, Ridley has not cleaned up the set. He now revels in the messiness. Gone is the wonderful narrative voice of Harrison Ford, explaining to us what was going on. Its not necessary because weve all seen the film before.

Adding a few moments amplifies the characters without a narrative megaphone. The film is strikingespecially from Sean Youngs Joan Crawford look to the smoky offices in the skyscrapers, and we still love Fords fey impersonation that loses nothing on Bogarts fey impersonator scene in The Big Sleep.

This 1940s detective film set in the 21st century lacks only Dooley Wilson, leaving Ridley Scott to play it again and again.

We wanted to see again if Deckard is really another replicant sent to retire other replicants. We have wondered about this for 30 years.

The Final Cut is brilliant. Its hard to do more than polish a diamond, even if you want to cut it into smaller segments to add more jewel facets.

In the meantime we wait for Ridleys deathbed version.

All the top reviews are of various editions of the film, so I thought I'd drop a review of the film itself.

This, singlehandedly, is the greatest scifi film of all time.

its genius is in its presentation of an unforgettable, frighteningly realizeable future world. it isn't just scifi, existential, noir, etc. it's all those things, like the real world. and like the real world, it doesn't exist to serve you the viewer, it exists independently of you, and meaning exists beneath the daily routines. Bladerunner, at its heart, is a simple enough detective story, but told with a master scifi artist's eye. bleakness, of light and hope, is its theme. paucity, of wealth and words, is its truth. monolithic corporations is its great adversary, not roy batty. overpopulation is the fatal flaw and, ultimately, humanity is the protagonist that may or may not survive, not just rick deckard. the romance wasn't sizzling - just an unsteady desperation that was just the right tempo for the world they lived in. and have you ever felt so heartbroken over the final defeat of the antagonist/victory of the hero? truly roy batty was one of the great complex characters in cinema.

Bladerunner is the alpha and omega of future noir - its better has not been seen since, and certainly not before. but it isn't for everyone. if you like your movies combustion heavy with much sprinting and mouth breathing, steer clear. This is a comparatively slow burn that subtly warps your worldview if you care even a bit about the fate of the world in which you live.
One of the best futuristic SciFi movies ever made. Note the date!
Awesome cut.

This film looks cool and has a great cast, but the problem remains that we don't get to know the characters very well. It's a game of chase from the beginning. A classic film, but it still feels unfinished.
Blade Runner is a 1982 American dystopian science fiction film directed by Ridley Scott and starring Harrison Ford.  Great "retro" movie, enjoyed even more the second time around.

This movie takes you on a thrill ride into the future, well of the future that the writers and directors thought it would be by now!  I too envisioned that we would have flying cars and clones by now, but I digress.  This was. A great suspenseful movie and it still holds up today.
Haven't seen this movie since it came out 30ish years ago.  I can wait another 30ish years to see it again.  Horrible soundtrack, bad editing and a 'meh' storyline.
I once bought Blade Runner and got some "director's cut" which omitted the Harrison Ford Voice over of the original. I had to buy some 4 disc set to get the original theater version.
Instead of writing thousands of words of blather about this rich, many-layered movie, I'll just say it's a great, great movie.  See it.
This is one of the best movies ever.
it really sucks.

Blade Runner is a classic movie.  I enjoy watching any and all of the various options available.  Rutger Hauer as Roy Batty was a completely deviant man and awesome actor in this movie.  Harrison Ford's character Rick Deckard, plays a good foil for Hauer's Roy Batty.  Hauer's character's obvious love for the Pris (Darryl Hannah) character is as evident as Deckard's mixed emotions for Rachael (Sean Young).

Graphically, this was an over the top movie.  However, considering it was directed by Ridley Scott, it was par for his undertakings.  Blade Runner is just a great movie.

The movie is definitely old, but I do remember the time it was released and it was a good movie. Watching it now, with the Final Cut, thrown in, it was a little outdated, meaning it no longer had the past impact. Still it is a good movie. Audio a little shaky, Video slightly better. 3.5 Stars.

I'm admittedly biased. I love the sort of cyberpunk, grungy take on the future that Blade Runner portrays, I loved Vangelis's soundtrack, and I loved the imperfect characters. I'm also a big fan of Ridley Scott especially when he gets to play around with lighting.

This final cut (different from the "director's cut" which wasn't really a director's cut but...well...it's complicated) is likely the closest you'll get to what Ridley Scott wanted...sorta.

Long story short, Blade Runner had a rough ride and this end result is what happens when Mr. Scott finally had some time (and was allowed to) recut the film. It means they cleaned up the mess that was introduced by others after Mr. Scott was fired from the film in post-production and builds upon some of the fixes that went into the director's cut (thank you for no voice-overs...we've got brains, we can figure it out). Granted some of those fixes were in the Director's Cut (the voice overs), but this Final Cut includes a laundry list of fixes to the print including some notables like having Joanna Cassidy actually look like Joanna Cassidy in all her scenes.

All in all, I really love what they did. It's cleaner and better. I don't agree with everything that was done but I'm not the director. If you haven't seen the movie, this is the version to see. If you have but haven't seen this cut, this is the version to see. If you have no idea what Blade Runner is and want to see a gritty Sci-Fi movie about what LA will look like in 5 years as envisioned 32 years ago, this is the version to see.

And, if you watch it and still feel the need to ask the question about Deckard that most people ask by the end of the movie, well, then Mr. Scott did his job.
Amazing film

What a great vision. This was good back in the day and twice as good today. I feel the directors version is much better that the original, but you do have to pay close attention to catch everything. If you have read the book and seen the original, then this is a must see for you.

The HD version had great picture quality and enhanced the movie all the more.  I loved the movie when it came out and was a real treat to see in HD.

I am a SciFi aficionado and consider this futuristic, dystopian movie to be the best every made.  The production, visual, attention-to-detail is superb thanks to Ridley Scott; the soundtrack is awesome enough to stand on its own as an amazing score provided by the master musician Vangelas; the story, based on Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep by Philip K. Dick, was masterfully edited and retold; and the actors Harrison Ford, Rutger Hauer, Edward James Olmos, Sean Young, Daryl Hannah and more.  Even today, it is still difficult to believe it is from 1982.
waste of time very boring harrison ford's bomb just a dumb movie and all the stars in the world would not make it any better.

If you're a scifi fan and haven't seen this movie, it's a must.  It has a great story, excellent acting and interesting cinematography.  Besides, you get to see very young Harrison Ford, Rutger Hauer and Darryl Hannah.

This is the BEST Sci-Fi movie ever conceived. It's so well done cinematically that you truly can suspend disbelief and dive into the rich characters and storyline. As for the Final Cut version, I think it lacks something without the narration by Decker but it's still so full of imagery and detail that missing narration is just nit-picking.  I've always thought there was so much care taken to bring realism to each shot - for instance, the crane shot from inside the police headquarters where the camera pans down past what looks like decades of dirt and refuse scattered around the ceiling of the office before elegantly dropping in on what could only be a well used office filled with a collection of items one might expect from years of police work.

Another aspect of this films importance in Sci-Fi is the prognostications of future tech brought to life that really build the foundation for so many scenes.

Wow  All 5 versions of Blade Runner all in one place!  Although I primarily bought it for the purpose of having The Final Cut on Blu-ray, everything else is just icing on the cake.  And its cool to show off to your friends and family who dig sci-fi.  It looks marvelous in high-definition as well.  I love the concept of this story.  Deckard may remember passing the Voight-Kampff, but was that memory implanted?...  You may believe in your reality, but is that belief real?  Philip K. Dick is masterful at presenting these questions through stories, and this movie is a masterful representation of the story.
If you like Philip K. Dick stories, Ridley Scott movies, or just generally a fan of sci-fi, then you better pick this up before your fellow nerds realize you haven't seen it yet.

I've seen this several times (different versions), and i like this cut.  It works better than the original - a cleaner ending was needed and we got one.  It's a sight to behold and the story draws you in.  Science fiction noir at its best.
I don't recall the first time I say Blade Runner, but I certainly know the great joy of a great story, filmed and cataloged in a great movie.
it was a great old Harrison Ford Movie . Well done many years ago .  when they going to bring out more so good
This is a classic ,I remember it when 1st released . It's dated now w/o the flash/bang CGI but still a good Sci/Fi thriller .

Sure, I haven't watched the so-called director's cut in many years, but seriously, I couldn't really tell the difference.  The movie itself needs no introduction, really.  After all those years, it's still very fresh, engaging and beautifully shot.  Storytelling is extremely tight and economical, stoic, even, totally wins my thumbs up.

Blade runner is often called "Blade Crawler" for its awful pacing. It doesn't really matter what cut you watch, the movie does not flow well. The movie can be commended for introducing some enduring styles in film, however many parts of the dialogue is just silly, the lighting (while trying to be stylish and giving an impression of a dystopian future) is annoying and often distracting and the cliche of a retired law enforcement guy being convinced to come back for one last assignment aside, if it difficult to care about any of the characters. Even Deckard. Those who enjoy the Neo-noir genre will inevitably enjoy this film but many (myself included) just do not find this film as a whole entertaining. I enjoy many different genre's of film, Sc-Fi included, however those who have yet to see the film (if you choose to watch it now) I find it extremely doubtful that at the end you'll say "That was awesome"!  Many will say "Oh but the film has so many complex themes about what it means to be human" and I say "I don't care, the movie is slow and boring". It is similar to Costner's "The Postman" in that you're not exactly mad that you took time to watch the film, BUT you have no desire to watch it again and you'd be hesitant to recommend it.
Delight to watch...with far reaching moral implications!  The topic is a highly contested one at the moment..."When do we grant Civil Rights to A.I.s?

A perfect complement to my silver cased limited dvd edition!

There has been much debate about the extras, the repackaging and marketing tricks that somehow make this not as good as it "should" be, but "you can't win if you don't play!" I'm just ecstatic that it is available! Some of my other favorite movies like Ken Russel's "The Devils" get no love at all!  It took me forever to find it - much less on a digital format! I eventually found a DVD, but the quality sucks!

I'd like to see more "cult" films get this treatment! A Clockwork Orange gets some love, but only in the form of a Kubrick collection. A Clockwork Orange has a similar following - small, but faithful!  Imagine an A Clockwork Orange with the same type of celebratory treatment with perks like rubber bloody eyeballs that you could wear on your sleeves or a little model of the tables in the moloko milk bar!

So, I say - support cult films whenever you can!

This is one of two great sci-fi thrillers that Ridley Scott made earlier in his career (the other is "Alien"). While it was largely ignored at the time of its release (in part, due to it being overshadowed by the march of the "Star Wars" franchise), it has since become such a cult classic that there are at least five different versions of it in circulation. This one, which does away with the "explanatory" voice-over by the title character, is I think, the best of the bunch. And among the excellent cast, Rutger Hauer is especially impressive as Roy. See it if you haven't; own it if you can.
An amazing view of what I think the vision of the future is going to be like. This movie is  still way ahead of it's time.

As a movie drawn from the novel" Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?" by Philip K. Dick, this modified adaptation represents an interesting study for a possible future filled with genetically manipulate creations that result in self-imposed moral consequences, while being driven by manifestations of genius and dark nobility. It presents a cast of notable characters. However, the directors cut is not my favorite pick among several other variations of the movie.

I have seen Ridley Scott's Blade Runner quite a few times, including the original run in a movie theater. I have loved it. I've read about how Alan King couldn't understand what was going on in the rough cut and took control away from Scott and added the narration. But I never before saw Blade Runner as Ridley Scott intended it. It is a work of genius. There are flaws: Harrison Ford was quite young then, and he hadn't quite developed his acting chops. Like the first three Stars Wars pictures, he's not really comfortable in his skin as an actor, but he looks great. Rutger Hauer does go way over the top. But the lead women are perfect and all the rest of the cast are impeccable. What is essential is the history of film with regard to Blade Runner is that it combines the most brilliant of noir with the most brilliant of sci fi. It set a standard that countless films have attempted to match. It remains in this version a movie that is actually about something and yet is mesmerizing. Ridley Scott. What can you say? He is the master's master.

Groundbreaking! After all these years, this movie still holds up. The practice effects look fantastic, the acting is great, and the cinematography is still effecting modern video game design (Cyberpunk 2077). See this version over the voice over with tacked on ending.

Bladerunner is a classic Sci-fi film! I remember when I first borrowed a friends VHS copy of it years ago and was in love (never gave back the VHS!) everything about this film is well done, Ridley Scott created a masterpiece in every way. The story is based on  Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?  a  novel by American writer Philip K. Dick. First published in 1968, human like robots serving humankind.
It is a story way before it's time, and which we see in film after film;Terminator, I-Robot, AI, The Machine, Aliens and more.
It is plausible that some day in the future we will have robots serving society, and the idea of Artificial Intelligence  is not long off, and the concept that AI will get out of control is a real concern to many.
It has love, drama, adventure, mystery, and imagination. An all star cast even back then;
Harrison Ford is perfectly cast as Rick Deckard, Rutger Hauer is also so believable as
Roy Batty, Sean Young is  a gorgeous Rachael and Daryl Hannah as
Pris is just plain amazing.
The lighting effects won an academy award, and for good reason, they are spectacular. The music by Vangelis fits the movie perfectly, I dream about it.
OK, I'm obsessed with the movie, yes, but it really is one of the top ten best Science Fiction films of all time, sits with The day the stood still (1), War of the worlds(1), Forbidden Planet, Star Man, ET, Star Wars, Alien and more.
If you are into Sci-Fi and you haven't seen the movie you are not into Science Fiction!
